Fisher River Agency
HODGSON, Manitoba
21st November 1947.

AIRMAIL

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I beg to refer to Requisition of October 17th last, covering One "Enterprise" Lumberman's Heater #50, and a sheet of Galvanized Iron and a sheet of Asbestos, for the Church Hall which is to be used as a second classroom for the Peguis South School. This requisition has not yet been filled, and it would be appreciated if delivery could be facilitated.

The desks have been received and set up some time ago, and the opening of this classroom is being delayed until the above noted stove is received.

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Extract from Inspector Patterson's report on the South Peguis Indian Day School dated March 15, 1948. Original on file 136-5-6.

Since this building was not intended as a classroom, lighting facilities are inadequate. The absence of shades on the windows with southern exposure results in serious inconvenience to students. It is recommended that translucent shades be provided to overcome this difficulty.

Another serious difficulty results from the lack of blackboard space. For a class of thirty-four students there is one section of blackboard 4' x 5'. About one-third of this has been broken out.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6244, file 534-5, part 4)
As requested in Mr. Neary's letter 136-4-5 (El) June 19th last, we attach hereto a Requisition covering material required to paint the Peguis South and Centre Day schools and residences.

The Contractor, WADELIUS PAINTING AND DECORATING, 110 Young Street, Winnipeg, Manitoba, will carry out the work as per his tender for Labour, namely, $300.00 for each school and residence.

It would be appreciated if the work could be done this year during the summer holidays.

P.M.
PGL/OT

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6244, file 534-5, part 4)
August 5, 1948.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Supt. Indian Agency, Hodgson, Manitoba.

With reference to your letter of the 23rd ultimo, the Departmental Purchasing Agent has been requested to secure the paint required for painting the Peguis South and Peguis Centre Indian Day School and teacher's residence.

It is noted that the labour for each school will cost $300. When forwarding accounts covering the cost of the labour, you should issue one voucher for the work done at the Peguis Centre School and a second voucher for the work done at the Peguis South School.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,

Peguis South Indian Day School.

Reference your 208-11 (127) of July 24th.

In view of the information contained in your letter I have today written to the young married couple I mentioned in my telegram, Mr. and Mrs. Fisher of Theford, Ontario. I have given them some details concerning the school set up as it exists in the hall and old school at Peguis South and have asked them to write you if they desire any further details.

I note from the annual report submitted by Miss Hodgson that this school is in need of interior decoration. Please have forwarded a requisition covering Kem-tone or similar wall paint to do the interior of the teacherage and possibly the classroom at this school.

I also note that the furniture in the teacherage is in need of some replacement. The mattresses in particular will require discarding. Please find attached three copies of our standard list of furniture which we are now supplying for our one room Indian Day Schools. Would you please prepare a requisition for the new furniture required at this school based on the standard list. It will be necessary for you to have quotations from Simpson's and Eaton's Western catalogues substituted for this list. These were obtained from Simpson's and Eaton's Eastern catalogues.
I am sending you this letter in duplicate in the event that you may wish to forward a copy to the Indian Superintendent concerned.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Peguis Indian Day Schools

With reference to your letter of May 4, 1949, file No. 534-5 (E). I am enclosing, herewith, Indian Day School Construction Reports #2, 3 and 4. I have changed these to plan #888 as requested. The three old schools are not in bad condition but will have to be covered with insul brick and the ceiling insulated.

I note your remarks regarding the putting of the schools together and that the Engineering Branch do not believe that this would be practical. I disagree with the Engineering Branch as these buildings are in good condition. If the cold air was run along the walls and taken from the back end of the school the gravity system would work. I have put furnaces in buildings and used the above method and same has proven satisfactory.

I do not consider the four-room school would be practical owing to the road conditions on this reserve and as you state this will not change for a number of years.

A requisition will be forwarded at a later date for material and labour on schools #2, 3 and 4.

The difficulty experienced at the Big Eddy School I believe has been caused by the fact that they did not put in a proper furnace. The present heating unit is a Camp comfort heater, boxed in, and there is not sufficient air intake, therefore the classrooms cannot be properly heated. When in Ottawa I intended to take this matter up with you and to request that a new furnace be put in this school. At the present time we have a furnace at The Pas, which was taken from God's Lake. This is a coal furnace but as there is a great deal of wood at The Pas and as the cutting of the wood employs the Indians I would not
recommend installing this furnace.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

RSD/MO
Enc.

P. S. - I would like to add that in all probability the power line will be extended to Hodgson, Manitoba, this year.

Re: Building of School at Fisher River Agency.

Regarding the above mentioned construction, since putting further considerable thought on this matter, I have come to the conclusion that it would be much better to construct three single school rooms, without residence, rather than building a three room school at the Fisher River Agency as originally suggested by me.

In the not too distant future, we will be having a constant increase of pupils, and two rooms in each case will eventually be very crowded.

I am attaching hereto a sketch - showing the additions which I recommend be made to the schools. They will be about ten feet from the present schools, and will be either on the sides or the ends. The plan I am forwarding calls for the heating to be placed in the centre of the two rooms, which would also allow for extra cloakrooms; and when the present rooms become overcrowded, we could take down the present cloakroom partitions and enlarge the rooms at very little cost - which would make provision for an additional ten children.

The present schools are not insulated, and as a result are very cold; and as you know by our previous correspondence, we are burning an excessive amount of coal. If the schools were built as I suggest, I would recommend putting brick siding on the outside of the old school as well as the additional classroom - thus making the two individual buildings and the centre heating plant look like one building.

- over -

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6244, file 534-5, part 4)
Also, I would recommend that the floors and ceilings in the old school be insulated. This would cut the heating costs, and by having the heating plant placed between the two rooms, it would cut down the cost of the whole heating system; and would, I think, make a much better heating unit.

The provision for furnace between the two schools should not be too expensive, and would draw the cold air from the bottom of both rooms, while the hot air would be expelled through vents near the ceiling.

Kindly let me know your thoughts re the above, and if you approve I will be able to get an estimate of the cost of building in between the two schools.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of one-room Indian Day Schools at No. 2, No. 3 and No. 4 Schools, on the Peguis Indian Reserve, in the Fisher River Superintendentency, Province of Manitoba, for the education of the Indian children living there;

THAT, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

THAT we have received, as a result of these advertisements, the following three tenders:

North American Buildings, Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. ....... $35,933.28
Jen's & Company, Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. ............... 47,365.00
Manitoba Engineering Co., Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. ...... 41,346.00

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that they comply with the conditions outlined on tender forms which had been prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

THAT Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the lowest tender, namely that of the North American Buildings, Limited, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, in an amount of $35,933.28;

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends the acceptance of the tender of the North American Buildings, Limited, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, for the erection of these one-room schools, for the amount of thirty-five thousand nine hundred and thirty-three dollars and twenty-eight cents ($35,933.28).

Respectfully submitted,

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 6 JULY 1949

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated June 11, 1949 from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of one-room Indian Day Schools at No. 2, No. 3 and No. 4 Schools, on the Peguis Indian Reserve, in the Fisher River Superintendency, Province of Manitoba, for the education of the Indian children living there;

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

That, as a result of these advertisements, the following three tenders were received:

North American Buildings, Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. $35,933.28
Joe's & Company, Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. 47,385.00
Manitoba Engineering Co., Ltd., Winnipeg, Man. 41,346.00

That the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that they comply with the conditions outlined on tender forms which had been prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

That Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the lowest tender, namely that of the North American Buildings, Limited, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, in an amount of $35,933.28; and

That funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the North American Buildings, Limited, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, for the erection of these one-room schools, for the amount of $35,933.28.

[Signature]

That the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of one-room Indian Day Schools at No. 2, No. 3 and No. 4 Schools, on the Peguis Indian Reserve, in the Fisher River Superintendency, Province of Manitoba, for the education of the Indian children living there;

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

That, as a result of these advertisements, the following three tenders were received:

North American Buildings, Ltd.,
Winnipeg, Man. ............ $35,933.28
Joe's & Company, Ltd.,
Winnipeg, Man. ............ 47,385.00
Manitoba Engineering Co., Ltd.,
Winnipeg, Man. ............ 41,346.00

That the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that they comply with the conditions outlined on tender forms which had been prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

That Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the lowest tender, namely that of the North American Buildings, Limited, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, in an amount of $35,933.28; and

That funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of the North American Buildings, Limited, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, for the erection of these one-room schools, for the amount of $35,933.28.

The Honourable
The Minister of Mines and Resources

5 January, 1950.

Mr. Thomas Emerson,
Supervising Principal,
Peguis Indian Day Schools,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

Expenditures - Peguis Indian Day Schools.

We have had several accounts forwarded to us recently by Mr. Wield. At the present time, no provision is made for supervising principals to authorize purchases for local school needs. All such matters must be referred to the Indian Superintendent concerned. Therefore, any articles which you consider are required for classrooms under your direction should brought to his attention and he, in turn, can apply to the Department for authority to expend the funds necessary.

I would suggest that you forward a requisition for standard items of school supply such as scribblers, pencils, etc., for use as a small emergency stock. Some of our other supervising principals have done this and it ensures that they have on hand a few essential items which can be used in the event of a teacher running short.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
30 December, 1949.

Mr. R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
538 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Peguis Day School No. 2A - Blinds.

You may make local purchase of the blinds covered in the attached requisition in the amount of $34.50.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Enclosure.

THIS INDENTURE made this day of one thousand nine hundred and forty-nine.

BETWEEN:

THE MANITOBA POWER COMMISSION, of the City of Winnipeg,
in the Province of Manitoba, hereinafter called "The Commission".

of the First Part;

- and -

HIS MAJESTY THE KING IN THE RIGHT OF THE DOMINION OF CANADA represented herein by the Department of Mines and Resources - Indian Affairs Branch, hereinafter called "The Department of Mines and Resources".

of the Second Part.

WHEREAS The Commission, for the consideration hereinafter mentioned, has agreed with the Department of Mines and Resources, to do, furnish and perform the works, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in the manner hereinafter described, in connection with the following work or works, namely:

Construct, erect, supply, install and maintain a 6900 volt transmission line together with the necessary poles, wires, transformers and other equipment required in connection therewith (hereinafter referred to as said "works") along a route from the Village of Hodgson, to the Peguis Indian Reserve, both in the Province of Manitoba and required to supply electrical energy to Peguis Indian Agent's Office, Hospital and Schools and other buildings enroute, provided they are not more than six hundred (600) feet from said transmission line, situated in and around Section Seventeen (17), in Township Twenty-six (26) and Range One (1), West of the Principal Meridian in the Province of Manitoba which forms a part of "The Peguis Indian Reserve".

NOW THEREFORE THIS INDENTURE WITNESSETH that the said parties hereto covenant promise and agree, each with the other, as follows:

THE DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES AGREES:

1. The Department of Mines and Resources hereby grants the Commission a license, easement or right-of-way over and upon that portion of their lands comprised by "The Peguis Indian Reserve", occupied by the said works, for the purpose of permitting the Commission to adequately operate and maintain the said works, in supplying electrical energy to the said buildings situated within the Peguis Indian Reserve.

2. That, for and in consideration of the premises and construction, erection, supply, installation and maintenance of the works, the Department of Mines and Resources will pay to the Commission by way of contribution toward the cost of the works, the sum of Six Thousand and Five Hundred Dollars ($6,500.00) and further provided, that for purposes of this contract the total cost of the works shall not include the cost of switches, additional poles, transformers or other equipment required to supply power to customers of the Commission along the said route of the transmission line.
3. That the said transmission line and distribution system erected and installed by the Commission will be the property of the Commission.

THE COMMISSION AGREES:

1. That electrical energy supplied by the Commission under any contract or contracts between the parties hereto to supply such energy from its distribution system within the Village of Hodgson, for transmission to a distribution system within the said Peguis Indian Reserve will be provided at a pressure of approximately 6900 volts.

2. That the works shall be constructed, erected, supplied, installed and maintained by the Commission.

3. That the Commission shall supply all material, labor, transportation, supervision and services required in the construction, erection, supply, installation and maintenance of the works, for the adequate supply of electrical energy or power for the said distribution system within the Peguis Indian Reserve which is now or may hereafter be erected, provided the distance between our line and any new buildings erected shall not be greater than six hundred (600) feet. Should the distance exceed six hundred (600) feet there shall be mutual absorption of cost or some other reasonable arrangement respecting same.

IT IS MUTUALLY AGREED:

1. That everything will be done and performed by each of the parties hereto to fully carry out and consummate all of the terms, covenants, provisions and conditions of this Agreement, to the end that after the execution of this Agreement the sole ownership, control and maintenance of said Works for transmitting and distributing said electrical energy and power to said buildings, shall absolutely vest in the Commission, its successors and assigns.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF The Manitoba Power Commission and His Majesty The King in the right of the Dominion of Canada, as represented by The Department of Mines and Resources have caused to be hereunto affixed their corporate seals, attested by the hands of their respective proper officers.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated May 25, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT it is in the interests of the administration of the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch and the Department of National Health and Welfare, Indian Health Services, to have electric power brought to the Fisher River Indian Agency in the Province of Manitoba, in order that power will be available for the Indian Administration buildings and the Indian Hospital;

THAT, in order to bring power to the aforementioned Administration buildings and Indian hospital, a line about eight and one-half miles long will have to be constructed;

THAT the Manitoba Power Commission have advised that they are willing to provide the electric power and construct the line if a contribution of $6500.00 is made towards the construction of the line by the two departments concerned, namely, the Department of Mines and Resources and the Department of National Health and Welfare;

THAT it has been decided to accept the offer of the Manitoba Power Commission and to divide the contribution between the two departments as follows:

Department of National Health and Welfare,
Indian Health Services - $3,250.00
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch - 3,250.00

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to execute an agreement, to be drafted, with the Manitoba Power Commission of Winnipeg, Manitoba, covering the above terms and conditions, accordingly.

Sgd. N.A. Robertson,
Clerk of the Privy Council.

MEMORANDUM

W. M. Cory
Legal Adviser

This is with reference to your memorandum of February 23, concerning the proposed draft agreement between His Majesty and the Manitoba Power Commission for the installation of a power line on the Peguis Indian Reserve.

Insofar as I am aware, this Department has never paid or undertaken to pay compensation to Indians in connection with any works or operations conducted by a power company or other body on an Indian reserve. To enter into any commitment of the kind in the present case would establish a precedent that might become extremely embarrassing.

Actually it does not appear to me that the Commission has anything to apprehend on the question of compensation, as the power line is for the benefit of the Indians as well as the Department and according to advice received from the Regional Supervisor there is no likelihood of any claim or compensation being made by any of the Indians.

TRLM/ITH
Director.

MEMORANDUM

W. M. Cory
Legal Adviser

This is with reference to your memorandum of February 23, concerning the proposed draft agreement between His Majesty and the Manitoba Power Commission for the installation of a power line on the Peguis Indian Reserve.

Insofar as I am aware, this Department has never paid or undertaken to pay compensation to Indians in connection with any works or operations conducted by a power company or other body on an Indian reserve. To enter into any commitment of the kind in the present case would establish a precedent that might become extremely embarrassing.

Actually it does not appear to me that the Commission has anything to apprehend on the question of compensation, as the power line is for the benefit of the Indians as well as the Department and according to advice received from the Regional Supervisor there is no likelihood of any claim or compensation being made by any of the Indians.

[Signature]

TRIM/TTH
Director.

MEMORANDUM TO [Signature]:

Please see your memorandum of the 18th ultimo with the attached papers in connection with the agreement between His Majesty and the Manitoba Power Commission for the installation of a power line on the Peguis Indian Reserve. I asked Major MacKay for his observations, and attached hereto is a memorandum of the 27th of February from the Director on the subject.

It will be noted that the Director is of the view that there will be no compensation payable in this case. It may be that the Power Company may be going down the road and not in individual Indian location. If this be the case, then the agreement as originally submitted is satisfactory. If it is to cross any Indian's holding, then no such crossing can be made without the Company paying an agreed compensation.

You may wish to discuss this matter further with the Director.

MEMORANDUM TO THE SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION.

This is with reference to the Legal Adviser's memorandum dated March 4th immediately hereunder and our conversation regarding the agreement between His Majesty and the Manitoba Power Commission for the installation of a power line on the Peguis Indian Reserve.

I discussed the matter further with Mr. Cory and I understand that the Indians have the right to compensation. If the Commission wishes to proceed then it must be prepared to pay an agreed compensation. It has been suggested that in view of the fact that the Indians will no doubt benefit from the installation of the power line then they would probably be willing to waive the right of compensation. This, of course, would be a matter to be taken up by the Commission with the individual Indians concerned.

You may wish to discuss the matter further with Mr. MacInnes when he returns.

We wish to acknowledge your of January 25th, to which was attached revised copies of contract drawn between the Minister of Immigration and the Manitoba Power Commission covering the establishment of electric service at Peguis Indian Reserve.

This contract is a revision of one supplied your department by the commission and we believe, generally speaking, the changes are necessary corrections as a result of the original draft being incorrect inasmuch as the setting up of the official Dominion Government signing agencies, etc.

However, one exception to this is the clause 1, under the commission agrees on page 2 as follows: "That the rights hereby granted shall not be exercised until such time as compensation satisfactory to any individual Indian affected or to the Indian Band is deposited with the Director of Indian Affairs."

As you know with this work the line is being constructed for the benefit of your department and we are acting as a contractor doing the work for you. Such being the case, we believe the only way we could agree to this clause would be to have an offsetting one whereby your department agrees to reimburse the commission to the full amount of any cost arising out of this undertaking.

If this is satisfactory to you, would you kindly have your department draft such a clause.

Yours very truly,

THE MANITOBA POWER COMMISSION

Ottawa, April 25th, 1927.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing the resignation of Mrs. I. Gauthier, teacher of the Pine Bluff R. C. Indian Day School to take effect June 30th, next. In reply I beg to say that the resignation of Mrs. Gauthier is accepted.

We are communicating with His Lordship Bishop Charlebois, The Pas, relative to the nomination by him of a suitable teacher to succeed Mrs. Gauthier and to begin duties on or about September 1st, next.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Ottawa, August 25th, 1927.

Madam:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant with reference to your salary cheque for the quarter ended June 30th last. In reply I beg to say that I have made further inquiries and find that this cheque left here on July 11th, as stated in my letter of the 15th instant, and it was addressed as follows:

Mrs. I. Gauthier,
Teacher,
St. Boniface, Man.

It is just possible that the postmaster at St. Boniface may have sent this letter to some of the schools in that town in the hope that a teacher of the name given on the envelope could be located. I, therefore, believe that it would be advisable to again discuss the matter with him.

If, however, you are unable to locate the cheque within the next week or ten days, you might fill out the enclosed bond of indemnity and forward it to me, when a duplicate cheque will be issued. I have made pencil notations on this form and, in filling it out, care should be taken to have the form properly completed in all respects. I regret that you are being caused this inconvenience but, as you have been informed, the cheque was forwarded promptly from here.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mrs. I. Gauthier,
428 Aulneau St.,
St. Boniface, Man.

Ottawa, August 23, 1927.

Right Reverend Sir:

Rev. Father Lajeunesse, of the Ottawa University, has forwarded your request for the transfer of Mr. P. Sicotte from the Nelson House R. C. to the Pine Bluff Indian Day School. This transfer is approved and I am writing to Mr. Indian Agent Waddy, asking him to give whatever help he can to Mr. Sicotte as he commences his new duties. Salary at the same rate - $85 per teaching month - will be allowed. I should be grateful if Your Lordship would let me have a nomination for the position at Nelson House.

I have the honour to be,

Right Rev. Sir,

Extract from the Report of T.H. Carter, Indian Agent, on the Payments of the Fisher River Agency for the year 1913. Original on File 427001-36.

PEKANGEKUM and DEER LAKE.

Pekangekum and Deer Lake have nothing educational, although at the latter place the people are working in a manner favourable to the establishment of a school in the near future.

(Sgd.) T.H. Carter,
Indian Agent.
Indian Agent's Office,
"The Halfway" P.O., Man.
February 17, 1916.

Referring to the estimates of the Fisher River Agency for the fiscal year 1916 - 1917 submitted in the month of September last in which I included in the list for salaries for day school teachers the sum of $500.00, each, for Deer Lake and Pekangekum, I respectfully beg to ask if the Department favourably considers the appointment of teachers for these two schools for summer terms.

Good work was done at Deer Lake as reported by myself in my statement of the annuity payments in the Fisher River Agency for 1915; at Pekangekum the people wish very much to have a teacher and will have in readiness a building, the walls of which were already erected when I last was in the reserve.

I am of the opinion that in both of these reserves the presence of a teacher will be of benefit. If allowed by the Department a small amount of school material will be necessary.

I have the honour to be

Your obedient servant

Sgd. T. H. Carter,
Indian Agent,
Fisher River Agency.
Ottawa, March 25, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated February 17th, last, which reached the Department on the 21st instant, in which you request that schools be opened for the summer term at Deer Lake and Pekangekum.

In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of your recommendation and a school to be open during the summer months only, may be conducted at each of these points.

With reference to Deer Lake, I beg to say that this school, which was open for a short period last summer, was conducted under the auspices of the Methodist Church and Reverend T. Ferrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools, is being written to and requested to secure the services of a teacher for the summer term of 1916.

With reference to the school at Pekangekum, I have to request that you will endeavour to secure the services of a teacher for this place. The schools at both of these points should be opened at as early a date as possible, and remain open, if possible, until September 30th. The Department will pay a salary at the rate of $60.00 per month during the period which these schools are open.

You should submit the name of the teacher you may secure to open the school at Pekangekum, together

T. H. Carter, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.
with the qualifications and experiences which the teacher possesses.

The Reverend Mr. Ferrier is being requested to communicate with you regarding the teacher whom he secures for the Deer Lake School and the date upon which he will commence duties.

You should forward a requisition for the amount of school material required at both these schools together with the full directions for shipping the same.

Your obedient servant

Assistant Deputy and Secretary
Brandon, April 1, 1916.

Mr T.H. Carter,

Dear Mr Carter:

I have just returned from Ottawa and while there, I discussed school matters on Lake Winnipeg district. The Department are willing to send a teacher to Deer Lake and also for Pekangekum for the summer. If possible will arrange for Elijah Sinclair to go to Deer Lake. I am not sure of a suitable man for Pekangekum, but Mr Benson of the school department informs me that he has written you to secure a teacher for Pekangekum; but I pointed out to him that the only mission work that had been done at Pekangekum, Little Grand Rapids and Deer Lake, had been done by the Methodist Church. In future we will be prepared to make a nomination for teacher. However if you have a suitable man to send out it will be all right for this year. If you have not made a selection, Mr Stevens might be able to assist you.

You might let me know what you have in view for Pekangekum and I have arranged with the Department for Elijah Sinclair to go to Deer Lake.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) T. Ferrier.
Sir,

In further reference to your letter No. 420320-I of the 25th, ultimo requesting me to procure a teacher for a summer school at Pekangekum, I respectfully beg to state that I have received a letter from the Revd T. Ferrier referring to the appointment of a teacher for Pekangekum, a copy of which I enclose.

I have no knowledge that any mission work has been done at Pekangekum by any church, but as Mr Ferrier states his church will attend to the appointing of a teacher for this place in the future, I most respectfully beg to recommend that Mr Ferrier be asked to secure a teacher for Pekangekum this year.

I have the honour to be

your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Fisher River Agency.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
Ottawa, April 26, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant enclosing a copy of a communication received by you from the Rev. T. Perrier in reference to the appointment of a teacher for the summer school at Pekangekum.

In reply I beg to say that if you have not been able to secure the services of a teacher to take charge of this school you should communicate with Mr. Perrier in regard to the matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. B. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

T. H. Carter, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
"The Hallway" P.O., Man.
Ottawa, May 31st, 1917.

Sir,

I have to advise you that the Department has decided to reopen the Deer Lake, Bloodvein and Pakangakum day schools for the summer months only.

Rev. T. Perrier is scouting teachers for each of these schools and he is being requested to advise you of the date upon which each will be ready to commence duties.

You should forward a requisition for the amount of school material required at these schools, together with full directions for shipping the same.

A salary of $300.00 will be allowed each teacher.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLean

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

T.H. Carter, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Ont.

Alexander Crate is at Pekangekum. He has had a good general education in English. Has a good general knowledge of trading and business and is splendidly suitable for Pekangekum School. Mr. Barner did not visit this school.

Extract from Report of Inspector J. R. Bunn on a trip made to Lake Winnipeg, dated August 23, 1919. Original on File 427001-25.

PEKANGEKUM.

The summer day schools at Little Grand Rapids, Deer Lake and Pekangekum did not operate this summer, I understand. In fact the work at these several reserves varies in operation so much that it is not very satisfactory from any viewpoint so far as I am able to figure it out. In fact so long as the Indians are of nomadic habits it is doubtful if schools can be of much advantage, as it is very difficult to assemble the children for classes owing to the erratic habits of life of the parents or guardians.

(Sgd.) Jno. R. Bunn,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, October 5, 1922.

Dear Sir:

Regarding the opening of a school at Pikangikum, for many years we supplied this by a summer teacher. During the war, the teachers on this river were withdrawn. We have re-opened the school at Little Grand Rapids, and would like permission to open up the one at Pikangikum about the beginning of the next fiscal year. Consideration of this will be appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, October 9, 1922.

Reverend Sir:

I have yours of the 5th instant, concerning the re-opening of the Indian Day School at Pikangikum next spring.

In reply I beg to state that Mr. Inspector Bunn and Mr. Agent Latulippe are being communicated with and you will be further advised.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aset. Deputy & Secretary.

Superintendent

Ottawa, October 9, 1922.

Sir,- re Summer Day School at Pekangekum for 1923.

I have to acknowledge your letter, number and date as given above.

This has reference to the suggestion of the Rev'd T. Ferrier, Superintendent of Methodist Indian Schools, that a summer day school should be opened at Pekangekum in the coming Spring of 1923. For the summer of 1922.

I visited this reserve during the past summer of 1922. I found conditions almost unchanged, so far as the residence of the Indians at Pekangekum is concerned.

I am asked to submit a recommendation as to the suggestion of the Rev'd Superintendent, and to communicate with Mr. Agent Latulippe so as to obtain his views about this matter.

I am of the opinion that the opening of this school is not advisable along the lines intimated. I feel certain that the results would almost Zero, and in a great measure the expenditure would be an improvident one. I arrive at this conclusion for the following reasons:

1. Summer Day Schools are unsatisfactory; the season being entirely too short to accomplish much, the results being therefore unsatisfactory for the pupils and to the teacher.

2. There is only a small part of the band who reside at Pekangekum in summer, not over one third of the band, and hardly that, the balance are divided and wander; a few have small gardens and live at the Old Fort, some live just west of Sandy Lake, and a few live near the Grave-yard, the balance wander. So that it will easily be understood why the children are not available. These Indians are a bunch of hunting Indians, Nomadic in their habits.

3. These Indians assemble once a year at the time of the Annual payments, and as soon as this is over, they scatter to the different places above mentioned.

4. It will be apparent that a school operated for Indians, that live as these do, will work under very unfavorable conditions and therefore the success of such work will be very doubtful from every viewpoint.

5. The Indians also disperse to their hunting grounds early in August, and are pretty well scattered for their winter hunting operations by the end of this month. They take their families with them, to the places where they intend to winter and hunt. This removes many of the children.

I have asked Mr. Agent Latulippe for his views in this connection and will forward same as soon as I receive them.

In my opinion it is only under very favorable conditions that Day Schools for Indians can be considered to meet with any success, that means a real benefit to pupils.

I have the honor to be,

your obedient servant,

Hope, appointed teacher to the Little Grand Rapids Indian Day School, came to Selkirk some two weeks ago for medical treatment, and he reported that on the 1st day of September there was not one child that attended school and do not expect them back till the next annual payment. From "The New Outlook" November 14, 1928.

Where Paganism Survives

Going inland to the east from Berens River on Lake Winnipeg, to the Manitoba-Ontario boundary, Mr. James Kirkness and family are opening school for the children of the Saulteaux bands at Pekangakum, a point from which eastern aviators have brought out strange tales of pagan rites. Forty portages have to be crossed by the intrepid missionary teacher in taking his wife and children to their new field of labor. Eastern papers have been demanding that the Churches do something to bring light to the Saulteaux.

Caring For the Saulteaux

Our Church has been trying for years to help these people who are nomads by the very necessities of their situation, and therefore unwilling to live long enough in one place to permit of the carrying on of a school. Rev. Arthur Barnier, superintendent of Indian Missions, and Rev. J. W. Niddrie, of Berens River Mission, visited with them in 1921, and held services. Either Mr. Niddrie or Rev. F. G. Stevens, of Fisher River Mission, has visited them once a year for the past ten years, making a toilsome journey, and meeting with some encouragement. A few families are remaining at Pekangakum for the winter.

Last summer our people in consequence of a request from the people at Pekangecum opened a day School at that point, and it has been operated all summer and winter with an average of somewhere around 20 children. Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have just returned from a journey up the Berens River, which has given me great cause for gratitude. Twelve years ago, when I first visited that part of the country, everything looked hopeless and indeed some people thought that it would be impossible ever to organize the work. Great changes have taken place. The work seems to me to be well established at Little Grand Rapids and Pekangekum. It is in regard to the latter place I wish to write a few words.

James Kirkness, as you know, had for many years a poor reputation, but during the past fifteen years he has been steadily improving in his habits of life. He has become a real leader in all good things among the people. I was quite surprised when I reached Pekangekum to find the improvements which he had made there; he has cleared off a fine piece of land, has erected a comfortable dwelling, he has been teaching school in a log building which he erected but which is quite inadequate so he has proceeded to get out a set of good logs and has put up the walls of a building which will be very comfortable and commodious when it is completed. I think he ought to be encouraged by the Department of Indian Affairs in this effort, and I would suggest that when the recommendation of the Agent reaches Ottawa, it shall receive very sympathetic consideration.

I was quite impressed with the transformation in the people who gathered while I was at Pekangekum. When I visited that place twelve years ago, the women and children ran away and hid themselves; I could not get near any one of them. At a distance I saw two little girls, not over seven years of age, crouching down by a camp fire, each with a dirty pipe in her mouth, pulling coals out of the fire to light their pipes. This was a sample of the general conditions then existent in the camp.
REPORT OF JOURNEY UP THE BERENS RIVER, Manitoba.

By Arthur Barner.

(From "The New Outlook")

By 8:10 a.m. Monday, July 21st, we were off for Pekangekum, 115 miles further up the river and about sixty miles north of Red Lake. By noon we were across the Ontario boundary line. The river here spreads out into Great Lakes, so there are not so many portages as there are in the west. The lake on which we camped is known as Sandy Lake, and is about one hundred miles long and about thirty miles broad. We reached the mission on the shores of Pekangekum Lake at 6:30 Tuesday evening, and by eight o'clock the people had gathered and we were holding an open-air meeting. If anything, the change at this place was more remarkable than that at Little Grand Rapids. It is nine years since I visited Pekangekum, principally because I knew that Mr. Niddrie was giving faithful service to the people. In July, 1928, one of our senior native members who was living at Norway House, was prevailed upon to go and live with this people. At tremendous physical labor, and with the co-operation of the Church and the Government, James Kirkness has built up a working plant which cannot be called adequate, but which has justified the effort, and in which he is working on a big piece of pioneer work. There are 225 souls in the band. When Mr. Kirkness went to Pekangekum two years ago these were all registered pagan and the government had been purchasing two years seventy have been baptized into the Christian religion and forty are members of The United Church of Canada. The contrast in conditions between the two struck me as a real work of the Spirit. When we approached the camp nine years ago the women and children disappeared, and they would not come near me. This time they came to the door nicely dressed and smilingly shook hands. Then the children looked ignorant and dull. I watched two girls, not more than seven years of age, squatting at a camp fire, each smoking a dirty pipe; now the children present had intelligent appearance, for the day school is well attended. There is real interest manifested in the services. The Kingdom of God is coming to Pekangekum. We called for a service to be held at 8:30 the following morning. Fifty people were present and we left them at 11:30 a.m. in the midst of hearty good wishes. We travelled until 5:30 that evening, when we reached Dunn Lake, where the people and the rest of the band were to meet for Treaty Payment. Here we found a village of tents belonging principally to the pagan people led by the chief, who had always shown opposition to our cause. We approached him.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have a letter from Mr. Walter Mitch, the teacher at Pekangecum, of which I shall give you the main outline. He is writing about the possibility of having a school at Poplar Hill. He says the people there evidently want a school and he thinks we could count on a pretty good attendance, because the Chief is in favor of having a school and the people are in the habit of doing as he suggests.

Mr. Mitch goes on to state that the Chief says the people would be willing to cut logs and build the school, being paid in rations only, and that this is the way the school at Pekangecum was built. He would like to know if the Government would supply the extra rations of flour, baking powder, tea, sugar and bacon, to enable the school to be built. He would like these to be made available, so that the Indians could cut logs this coming Spring. He says that when he takes his holidays at the end of June, he would be glad to move down to this place while they built the school. In that connection, he says that he thinks there is very good reason why they should be encouraged, because the Indians now find it difficult to catch enough fish for their families at Pekangecum. He thinks that the Band might very well be divided, - which I gather they are, as a matter of fact.

In this letter, Mr. Mitch says he asked the Chief to find out if the people would like to have a school at Poplar Hill, say, for half the year, and at Pekangecum for the other half, and the report is that the people would like that. They hope the Indian Agent will let them have a school at Poplar Hill, where there are about thirty children of school age and lots younger. Would you let us know if there is any possibility of the needs of this district being met in this way - that is, by the Government providing rations while the Indians cut logs this Spring and then erect the school next summer, under the supervision of the teacher; and also whether the Government would make a small grant for the supply of spikes, shingles, windows, furnishings, &c.

Thanking you in anticipation of your consideration of this matter, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter No.200-11A. of yesterday's date relative to enclosed copy of letter received from Mr. Dorey, Board of Home Missions.

For your information I wish to point out that the Pekangekum is divided and living at three different points, Pekangekum, Poplar Hill and at Duck Lake. If a new school was built at Poplar Hill it would only be a short time until one would be requested for Duck Lake.

At Pekangekum a new school was built a few years ago and which has never been finished properly. Shingles etc. was provided by the Department but the Indians refused to freight same from Berens River. This material remained at Berens River until this fall and while at Berens late in the season I distributed this material to needy Indians of the Berens River Band. It was badly weather-beaten and would soon not be fit for anything.

In view of the manner in which the Pekangekum school was built and the Indians refusal to carry lumber inland as it is so hard to handle in canoes, I cannot recommend the building of a new school at Poplar Hill, which is not on Reserve land.

Dear Sir:

When treaty was being paid this summer it was noticed that a very small attendance was shown on all reserves during the month of April and May. At which time the Indians take their families and move out to the marshes for the rat hunt. It was suggested that it might be possible to arrange to have the annual holidays during that period and the schools kept open during the summer months when the Indians are all together on their reserves.

Several of the teachers who were approached though that if this plan were adopted it would certainly insure a more regular attendance.

Dear Sir,

I have no doubt the arrangement would prove satisfactory for Little Grand Rapids, but at Poplar River and Big Grand Rapids the teachers are also the clergy and it may be more difficult to make this arrangement. I think these people in the north should get out each year for holidays and this should be considered.

At Berens River, I hardly see the need for changing the present arrangements. The R.C.M.P. are stationed here and are available, usually at treaty time. I am further advised that the women and children do not always accompany their husbands, a custom more extensively practiced further inland.

I beg to submit the following report on the Sioux Lookout Agency inspected during the month of June 1946.

SCHOOLS:

At Pikangikum a day school is operated for ten months. Mr. Smith is the teacher in charge. He has no teacher's certificate. There are 23 on the roll with an average attendance of 19. School was not in operation as the building was required for the paying of treaty.

This is a log building. The floors are in fair condition. There are two windows on each side of the building. The lighting is poor. The school is furnished with home-made benches, a table and chairs. The roof is covered with rough lumber over which is roofing paper. There is a large box heater. The blackboard consists of one piece—16 feet long—which is not sufficient.

There are ten or twelve families who remain around Pikangikum during the winter, consequently the attendance is fairly good. This is a difficult place to operate because it is very isolated and no one wished to remain for long. It is difficult to reach except by plane and thus transportation is expensive.

At Pikangikum there is a log school house and a separate teachers residence, neither of which are in very good condition but should serve the purpose for a year or two or until such time as we can put up a new building similar to the plans we have. There is a Hudson's Bay Post about half a mile from the school, here staple provisions can be purchased, but anything apart from staples should be brought in from Red Lake. The teachers residence is supplied with a full line of dishes, pots and pans etc. consequently all he will have to be concerned with is food supplies.

Indians at Pikangikum are rather primitive and very few can speak even a word of English, therefore it may be necessary for the teacher to secure the services of an interpreter, who is employed by the Hudson's Bay Co. This may be worked out on a part time basis but I feel that it is necessary and that some allowance should be made.

A soft ball outfit should be supplied also football, skipping ropes etc.

Yesterday morning I had a visit from Mrs. Spence, mother of the university student sent as a seasonal teacher to the Pekangekum Indian Day School. In a letter sent to his aunt, he made the following observations:

"The house is filthy and running with mice. The Indians alone are enough to get one down. Many of them have T.B. and running T.B. arms (although as yet I have none in the school) and T.B. joints. Mrs. Hancock, (H.B. manager's wife) has never seen any place where the people die so fast. It is little wonder that the Indians are decreasing. Their tents are just in front of me and of course they never think of doing anything with the entrails of their fish but throw them out the tent flap. As a result there are plenty of flies as well as mosquitoes, black flies, etc.

The children don't want to learn English. Although quite a few understand, they will not speak it unless they are forced to. --- This morning I had 33 children all speaking Indian and climbing around. I really don't think it is worth staying here for the money. I feel that I would be going back to university tired and run down. I have lost some already but I think I can gain it back when I get straightened out. - - I have not decided how long I will stay here."

His mother is very worried about him and I have therefore instructed Mr. Swartman to accept Mr. Spence's resignation.

I wish to acknowledge Colonel Neary's letter of June 12 with respect to the Pekangekum Day School.

I was not surprised to learn that Mr. Spence had decided to resign, although, to date, we have not been informed whether he has actually left Pekangekum or not.

However, there was nothing that a little soap and lots of water would not correct. Upon the arrival of our Treaty Party at Pekangekum, we swept out the building and it appeared that Mr. Spence had not done much in the way of cleaning during the week he was there, prior to our arrival. Dr. Bell, Mr. Grew, Constable Thomas, and myself slept in the building for two nights and it is true that there were signs of mice.

The Indians of this particular band are rather primitive and have had no training, of course, in modern housekeeping. They depend on their dogs to clean up the fish entrails, but as I see it, Pekangekum offers a challenge to a man of determination and strong character. Mr. Spence did not tell me at the time of our visit that he was contemplating resigning, although he did say that he might not be there until September 1. In my opinion, he is about the weakest of all the summer Day School
teachers we have in the Agency and it would be just as well if he returned home because I am sure that he would be able to accomplish very little by remaining on the job all summer.

I was very much impressed with the other boys, particularly Alec Short at Deer Lake and Johnny Strang at Bear Skin. These lads are really working under difficulties and deserve a lot of credit if they stick it out for the season.

Referring to your telegram of July 15 with respect to the Pekangekum Day School, I believe it would be a good move to place a teacher there on a year-round basis. It would require a few months to induce the parents in the vicinity to send their children in to school, but with perseverance and patience, I think this could be accomplished. I might explain that only a small proportion of the Pekangekum Indians live right on the Reserve. They are scattered over an area of from a mile to forty or fifty miles from the Reserve, but I believe if we could show them that we meant business in the operation of school many more of the families would make their headquarters right at the Reserve.

The living quarters have already been described, and while they are alright as make-shift arrangement, I would suggest that plans be made to establish a new school with teacher's quarters in the not too far distant future because the present set-up does not give much inspiration either for the teacher or for the Indians. It might be advisable to have the student who is interested in teaching there read Mr. Spence's report on the situation, as well as ours, in order that he will be fully acquainted with all angles of the situation.

The Pekangekum Indians are without a doubt quite primitive and to date have absorbed very little in the way of education or religion. Many of them hold to the aboriginal belief in good and bad spirits, also medicine. Nevertheless they are good people, and as I have already mentioned in previous correspondence, they offer a challenge to the teacher or missionary, and also to the Indian Superintendent.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Last Spring I understand that the Department appointed Mr. Cecil Graeme Spence to act as summer teacher at Pekangecum. We were delighted to co-operate with the Department -- or probably to have the Department co-operate with us, -- and were prepared to assist Mr. Spence in doing missionary work. Now he has come back and the following is an extract from his letter:

"As you know I was appointed summer teacher at Pekangecum by the Government. I also intended to do missionary work. I was very enthusiastic about my work, having looked forward to it all winter and spring. However when I reached there I found that conditions had deteriorated during the war years. Although I expected bad housing conditions, I was not prepared for the poor health conditions. For the last decade tuberculosis has been on the increase. As a result it is not a very healthy place to be right now.

"The children lacked discipline to such an extent that I found individual instruction the only way to help them. You can understand that one of the greatest difficulties in the teaching of Indian children, who do not understand English to any degree, is the lack of a clear medium of expression. One has to show them before they understand. This naturally entails close contact with students suffering from T.B., as it is impossible to isolate known cases of it there and hospitalization is almost unheard of, facilities being so short outside. Most of the very numerous deaths there are from T.B. There are also open running T.B. Sores and joints among the people and children."

I hope something can be done to improve conditions at Pekangecum. I shall be glad to know what the Department proposes to do, if anything.

Yours sincerely,

GD.MIT

March 29, 1949.

Dear Dr. Best:

Pekangekum Indian Day School.

I have had a large number of applications from University students interested in teaching in our seasonal schools.

You will recall our discussion last year concerning Mr. Spence and I am anxious to obtain another male University student. This time we require one with some experience in an isolated place. There are three applications which I believe would prove of suitable calibre:

(1) C.H. Brown, Age 36, C.E. Six years R.C.N., Now Second Year Student in Anthropology, University of Toronto.

(2) J.K. Arnold, Age 27, C.E. Seven years Canadian Army, Now attending Third Year Carleton College.

(3) James Bond, Age 31, R.C.N. Service, Graduate Queens University, Now Anthropology Student at the University of Toronto and keenly interested in spending the summer at Pekangekum in order that he can work on his thesis leading to his Masters Degree. His religion is Baha'i.

If you are interested in writing directly to any of the above students, please do not hesitate to let me know and I will send you their individual addresses.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Doctor Best:

As agreed in your letter of April 19, I have written to Mr. Bond concerning the Pekanekum Indian Day School. I expect he will be accepting the position and will advise you further when he does.

Concerning the Deer Lake School, we have already offered Mr. Brown another position in an Anglican seasonal school at Waswanipi. I am not certain as yet whether the former teacher, Mr. Short, will be returning to Deer Lake. If not, then I have another likely applicant in Mr. Peter Walmsley. He is highly recommended by his Professors at the University of Toronto and, like Mr. Bond, intends to do research work in Anthropology as well as to teach this summer. He is a veteran of five years in the Army, most of which was spent overseas as a stretcher bearer in the Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps. He also has experience as an educational sergeant.

I will write to you again when this matter has been settled.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard S. Beary,
Superintendent of Education.

I have received a letter from the Councillor of the Pekangekum band asking for some hinges, lock, door and nails, for the building used as a school, and also asks for some provisions while the building is being erected.

The building used last summer is a building used as a residence and the property of the Councillor. The block intended for the school is already erected, this I saw at the time of the annuity payments, but I do not know if it is the custom to provide provisions for the people while building, but it would seem to be in order to make a small grant for this purpose as the men cannot hunt while at this work.

If the Department allows the request of the Councillor I would respectfully suggest that these supplies be ordered from the Hudson's Bay Co.'s store at Little Grand Rapids.

Replying to your letter No. 420,318-5 of the 22nd ultimo requiring a report and estimate of the present state and the cost of completing the building intended for a school in the Pekangakum Reserve, I respectfully beg to say that the building as I saw it last consisted solely of logs hewed and built up to the required height of walls;

The material required is 10 rolls of roofing, 4 windows, 1 door with hinges and lock complete, also 100# nails.

Ottawa, April 8, 1929.

Dear Mr. Hiddrie:

I have your letter of the 16th ultimo, with reference to the day school activity at Pakangakum. I am pleased to note that some success is being realized. While it is true the Department did not grant any supplies for a midday meal or allow a stipend for the teacher, we did send, by mail, addressed to James Kizness, in your care, readers, scribblers, etc., for the classroom work. These went forward about the first week in September, last. If a supply is now needed, if you will prepare a requisition, indicating what should be allowed, the Department will give favorable consideration.

I regret that there are no funds to assist in the erection of a school building and a teacher's residence at Pakangakum. The Department believes it advisable to give this school a thorough trial before undertaking capital expenditure.

Dear Mr. Pherson:

I am just in receipt of a letter from our Superintendent Rev. Mr. Barner, who advises me that he, upon his recent visit to Ottawa, talked over the situation at Pakangoom regarding the erection of a school building with Indian Department Officials, and I am instructed to forward to you as soon as possible an estimate of the approximate cost of such building, with a request that you forward same to Ottawa at your earliest convenience. You will notice that I have made the figures as small as possible on account of the conditions of times; but I think kindness can get quite a lot of help out of the people and this accounts for the low figures submitted.

With very kind regards and wishing you and Mr. Millidge the seasons greetings,

Very Respectfully Yours,

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

When in Ottawa you mentioned the case of Pekanecum and suggested that it might be possible to secure a grant which would cover the expenses in completing the school building, the walls of which have been erected at the expense of the missionary at Pekanecum. I wrote to Mr. Middrie asking him to prepare an estimate and forward it to the Indian Agent at Selkirk. He has kindly sent me a copy which I am enclosing for you.

I appreciate very much your interest in this matter. When I was at Pekanecum in 1930 I found Mr. Kirkness carrying on his school work in a very inadequate building, both too small and with a roof so low that it was oppressive, so I shall be very glad if it is possible to facilitate this work during the coming summer.

With kind wishes,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

At 2.30 p.m. the party left by planes for Pekangekum and arrived at 3.30 and by 4 p.m. were making the payments, continuing until 9 o'clock. On Saturday 23rd June the treaty payments were completed and a meeting of the Band held and was brought to a close about 2 pm. I would like at this time to call attention to the condition of the Day School on this Reserve. It is a small log building, 16 x 18, hopelessly inadequate to house a teacher and 30 children. The roof is covered with spruce bark and leaks like a sieve, a most unsanitary and unhealthy condition, as well as uncomfortable. I trust that when the time comes for building schools, Pekangekum will be one of the first on the list to receive attention.

Seikirk, M., July 29th, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith snaps of the interior and exterior of the Pekanekum School House which may be the poorest school building in the Dominion. The roof is covered with spruce bark and offers little or no protection from the rain and storm.

The Indians of this reserve under the leadership of their teacher & missionary, Mr. Richard Schuetze have shown marvelous enterprise in their efforts to obtain a new school. They have gone to the bush and cut logs 22 feet and 30 long without a horse or an ox on the Reserve, organized companies of men and carried these heavy green spruce logs out on their shoulders. You will notice that the logs are splendidly hewed and the block pretty well on its way to completion, with plenty of logs on the ground to finish the job. These Indians are excellent axmen and I have never seen finer dove-tailed corners anywhere, what they need now is material for shingles, flooring and sheathing. They have taken out their own stringers, joists, rafters etc. It will not cost much to complete the building. They should have six windows, one door and one screen door as well as screens for the windows, also nails and shingle nails.

They are entirely without desks in the old school and the old forms hewed out of logs as shown in the picture, but these they say could wait for another year, but they must have a heating stove and a table and chair for the teacher.

If the department will come to their assistance and crown their splendid efforts to obtain a school, $250.00 will complete the job, including the stove, table and chair.

In the event of this material being shipped the Indians have offered to freight same from Berens River, free of charge. The regular price is $7.00 per 100 lbs. I really think they are entitled to rations while freighting and while working on the school, another $50.00 would take care of this, say $300.00 in all to complete the school, Labor, material, stove, table and chair and perhaps in another year we could have the desks.

If approved kindly advise at earliest convenience.
so that the same may be freighted in time to complete the building while the weather is still good.

I need hardly say how much I appreciate and admire this splendid effort on the part of the Pekangekum Band and their leader Mr. Schuetze to make the completion of a new school so much easier to accomplish than it otherwise would have been and I sincerely hope their objective can be obtained.

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Selkirk, Man., March 7th, 1938.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 125-13-5 of the 3rd. instant relative to school requisition for the Pekangekum Indian Day School.

Please be advised that the reason this requisition was forwarded by the school-teacher, Mr. A.Walter Mutch, at this time, is due to the fact that last fall quite a bit of difficulty was experienced in getting the school supplies in to Pekangekum. This year he decided that he would requisition earlier, before the in-between season set in, then his supplies could go forward when navigation opened in the spring.

This school is all that Mr. Mutch states in his requisition. The roof is covered with bark and the building is not lined at all. Also stove pipes are badly in need of being replaced.

Shingles were supplied for this school and shipped as far as Berens River. However, the Indians from Pekangekum refused to freight from Berens River. This material was forwarded to Berens River by the former Indian Agent Irwin and had been at Berens River exposed to the weather for two years previous to my re-instatement. This material was badly weather-beaten and in order to salvage some value from it, I instructed the R.C.M.P. at Berens river to issued same to the needy Indians at Berens River.

I would suggest that further shipments for the Pekangekum School be sent via Red Lake, Ont. which is much closer to the Reserve than by Berens River.

Yours very truly,

E.McPherson
Indian Agent.

The secretary.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE RE SIUX LOCKOUT AGENCY.

Information obtained from Mr. Swartman during his recent visit to Ottawa.

DAY SCHOOLS : PIKANGIKUM

The teacher, Mr. Rushforth, looks after the distribution of destitute supplies and food stores in a warehouse at the school. The school is operated under the auspices of the United Church and has from 5 to 35 pupils. The Indians of the Pikangikum do not co-operate by sending their children to school. Hot coffee and biscuits are distributed during the day to the school children.

April 2, 1940.

EXD.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 14th ultimo the Department considers it advisable to return the requisitions you forwarded in connection with the Pekangekum School in order that they may receive further consideration.

When you visited the Department in February I understand from Mr. Christianson, Superintendent of Indian Agencies, that you stated that the attendance at this school varies from 5 to 35 pupils and that the Indians do not co-operate by sending their children to school. Under these circumstances the Department does not see the necessity for spending the amount of money you request on the building. Would it not be possible to put it in repair with a smaller expenditure?

The supplies requested for midday meal purposes appear excessive and certainly the quantities requested are more than last year.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Reference is made to Mr. Hoey's letter of April 2nd, file 125-13-5, concerning building materials, etc., requisitioned for the Pikangikum Indian Day School.

When discussing schools with Mr. Christianson I must have been referring to the Fort Hope School rather than Pikangikum. I regret not having made myself clear on this point. It is true, the Indians do not cooperate very fully but it is felt this will be eventually overcome, especially if the Hudson's Bay Company appoint a Whiteman instead of an Indian or Half-breed to manage their Pikangikum post.

At the time of my visit to Pikangikum last July the school building was in a rather deplorable condition. The building was very poorly constructed. The roof leaked badly which in turn had affected the floor. I promised the teacher an endeavor would be made to obtain sufficient material for repairs and I believe the enclosed requisition contains only the minimum requirements if the school is to continue in operation.

I am not fully cognizant of the arrangement or agreement between this Branch and the United Church under whose auspices the school is conducted, but I do believe if the school should be closed for the duration of the war, it would not make a great deal of difference insofar as the welfare of the Band as a whole is concerned. The Missionary Teacher serves a very useful purpose in issuing destitute rations but other arrangements could possibly be made.

Yours very truly,

Gifford Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

During my visit to Pekanjicum Indian Reserve I found that the roofing on the school was badly in need of repairs. This was caused by high winds, also the boards forming the roof vary in thickness which does not permit a good job to be made with the roofing paper. We had a request from the Missionary teacher, Mr. Smith, also from the Chief and Councillors that steps be taken to repair the roof. For a roof of this description cedar shingles are the only solution. The roof on each side measures 33 feet by 18 feet which would mean sufficient shingles to cover about 1200 square feet. The cost of shingles purchased locally and delivered at Hudson is $6.50 per M. or a total cost of $71.50.

Please advise if authority will be granted for the purchase of this material. Requisition for same is enclosed.

Report re 1944 Annuity Payments
Sioux Lookout, Agency

Treaties 5 and 9

June 7:
We left for Pekangikum at
3 p.m. arriving at 4.15.

June 9:
The school here is in urgent need of repairs, especially
the floor. It was proposed that the Indians whipsaw sufficient
lumber for a sub-floor and then I would go into the matter of the
Department furnishing enough flooring to cover the floor. Mr. Smith
the Missionary teacher is doing a fair job with the school work. He
labours under quite a handicap with more or less primitive
conditions at Pekangikum, in addition to the Band as a whole being
so little advanced. A large number of them are still pagan and
prefer native medicine and superstition to anything the white man
can offer for their melioration. It is unfortunate that I am unable
to visit this Reserve more frequently than just the annual call for
Treaty payments. I feel that some progress might be made if we
kept exhorting and encouraging them to improve themselves.
In the late afternoon a plane called to move us to Deer Lake where
we arrived at 5:30 p.m. At Pekangikum arrangements had been made
with William Everett to accompany the party as interpreter to Deer
and Sandy Lakes. His services were invaluable.

G. Swartman,
Indian Agent

Ottawa, April 6, 1945.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

In your letter of March 13 you request authority to purchase 1,000 ft. of flooring for use at the Pekangekum Day School. The request was submitted to the Purchasing Branch, who state that they have obtained one quotation on Norway Pine at $65.00 a thousand. The North American Lumber and Supply Company did not quote but advised the Purchasing Branch that they would have fir flooring in their Hudson yard later in the season. Please let me know at once if Norway Pine flooring would be suitable for the purpose required.

I would also like to know from which firm you obtained the price of $90.00 a thousand for fir flooring. This information was contained in your letter of March 13, but you did not state the name of the firm.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge Mr. Phelan's letter of April 6th, File 125-13-5, with respect to flooring for the Pekangekum Day School.

The Norway pine flooring would serve the purpose quite as well as fir, especially if we were supplied with a gallon of paint to cover the surface. The quotation of $90.00 per thousand was received from the Beaver Lumber Company. This was for fir flooring, 4" in width. However, it is recommended that the red pine flooring be supplied if possible, instead of fir, as the cost to land the material at Pekangekum will be considerable. It is suggested that the firm supplying the flooring be required to tie same in bundles of approximately 50' each.

G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Pekangkum Indian Day School

Yesterday morning I had a visit from Mrs. Spence, mother of the university student sent as a seasonal teacher to the Pekangkum Indian Day School. In a letter sent to his aunt, he made the following observations:

"The house is filthy and running with mice. The Indians alone are enough to get one down. Many of them have T.B. and running T.B. areas (although as yet I have none in the school) and T.B. joints. Mrs. Hancock, (H.B. manager's wife) has never seen any place where the people die so fast. It is little wonder that the Indians are decreasing. Their tents are just in front of me and of course they never think of doing anything with the entrails of their fish but throw them out the tent flap. As a result there are plenty of flies as well as mosquitos, black flies, etc.

The children don't want to learn English. Although quite a few understand, they will not speak it unless they are forced to. --- This morning I had 39 children all speaking Indian and climbing around. I really don't think it is worth staying here for the money. I feel that I would be going back to university tired and run down. I have lost some already but I think I can gain it back when I get straightened out. - - I have not decided how long I will stay here."

His mother is very worried about him and I have therefore instructed Mr. Smartman to accept Mr. Spence's resignation.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education

"Dec. 20th, 1896.

"Dear Mr McLaughlan,

"In reply to your enquiry re trading, I beg to state the following: Last summer after treaty payment the Hudson Bay Co's officer, J.K. McDonald, Esq., closed up the store here and removed to Norway House, promising to return in the fall. However, he did not, but he sent a letter to Jacob Nanawin, the head man of the band, saying, the Company were not going to trade here this winter. Hence I was left in a strait, not knowing what to do, being utterly opposed to trading, especially as the Agent and Mr Flett had said to my people, if you stand up for the missionaries nobody will help you, and I found out that those who had aided Mr Mackay had received some assistance from Beren's River. I had helped my people as far as I could without running myself on a rock, expecting a trader coming, but none came, and as they were in actual need I felt that I could not afford to sacrifice my influence over them, and leave them to the Wolf. So I decided to assist them all I possibly could, and accept of their fish and fur until a trader could be induced to come in, although it cost me much pain and trouble. Now that Mr Campbell has agreed to come in, I have turned all over to him to reimburse my outlay, and have ceased having anything more to do with trading. Hoping this will meet with your approval, ever remaining,

"Your obedient servant,

(Signed) Joseph Dargue."

**JUNE QUARTER**

First and second weeks in April the ice was unsafe and no children attended school. For the remainder of the quarter the people were away to fish stations, etc., taking their children with them. June 1st, teacher away until the 24th visiting Winnipeg Methodist Conference.

**SEPTEMBER QUARTER**

The people came home from fishing 16th July for Treaty. School was opened but so many calls and sick to attend had to close. After Treaty people all left again.

School called August 21st, no attendance until 24th. August 30th school is open for only 1 or 2 hours each day. There are several very bad wounds have to be dressed twice a day and several sick people have to be attended. September 1st, no attendance.
