Sir:

I have the honor to report having made an inspection of the Poplar River School on the 12th February, 1912.

I found 16 children in School at the time of my visit and an average of 14 for the three months past.

I have rarely found children so wretchedly clad or parents so desperately poor as those on this Reserve. There has been a great deal of sickness during the year and children were unable for this reason to attend School as stated in report.

The teacher is not qualified as a teacher and does not regard himself as under obligation to teach school were his ministerial duties interfere therewith. He regards himself as preacher and visitor at the homes first and in work that he can do in the School is regarded by him as his secondary duties.

Last fall the people were away at the Fall Fishery for a long time and no School could be kept because the children were with them.

I cannot speak highly of School work done and think that the School teachers office and work of the missionary should be separated and that one man's whole attention should be given to the School.

As to details the report covering this letter will give full information.

Black River is twenty miles by water from Poplar River and, as is generally known, the Indians take their families along with them so that the constituency for the school is beyond reach. If the Department would provide suitable accommodation at Black River, Mrs. Caldwell, the teacher, has intimated that she would be very glad to continue the school at that point.

"Owing to the situation thus created, the Indian Agent paid Treaty at Black River this summer instead of at Poplar River.

"I would, also, draw the attention of the Department to the fact that Mr. Caldwell has been throughout the entire year caring for the needy and destitute on the reserve without any remuneration from the Government, and as the Indian Agent visits Poplar River only once a year, Mr. Caldwell has the full responsibility of their oversight.

"In view of the facts above stated, I feel that the Department should carry the expense of the school at Poplar River for the entire school year, and I shall be glad to receive a cheque for the balance of the teacher's salary for the quarter ended June 30th, 1931."

Sir:

Replying to your letter No.125-14-1 of 16th July, referring to the condition of the Poplar River School House, I beg to state that I fully intended making a thorough inspection of this building at treaty time, as instructed in your letter of 10th January, but on the day the treaty party were leaving Selkirk for the Lake Reserves, Mr. Caldwell notified me that all the Poplar River Indians were at Black River and suggested that the payments be made at that point. The Indians with their families were working for one of the Fishing Co. Accordingly I went to Black River and made the payment and was prevented from visiting the Reserve.

Poplar River is, in my opinion, one of the poorest Reserves on Lake Winnipeg, as the Indians have no work and the winter trapping is poor. The Indians migrate to Black River every spring and fall, fishing in the summer and taking out cord wood for the Company in the winter. I suggested to the Band two years ago, when that Reserve was burnt out, that they move to another point on the Lake, where they would have a better chance of earning a livelihood.

I am aware that the Poplar River school is in poor condition but no worse than at some other Reserves where there is a larger and steadier attendance for the full school term and I would not recommend that any expense be added at present.

As regards to the statement that Mr. Caldwell has full responsibility in this Reserve, I beg to state that Corporal Stewart, R.C.M.P., Detachment at Berens River was instructed by Mr. W.M. Graham, Commissioner, to oversee this point and report to the Selkirk Agency. He made several patrols during the winter and was authorized to look after the destitutes and make what purchases from the Hudson Bay Co he considered necessary.

Dear Mr. Barner,

I have just returned from a visit to the people at Thunder Lake, and have time to catch up on outgoing mail. I found the people very well and very pleased to see me. They have had a fair trapping season, but have been handicapped by the unfavourable weather, rain and delayed snow at the early part of the season, and too much snow, mild weather and overflow of the rivers latterly. In general, they have had a very good winter, much better than last year, and the prospects for the Spring catch are excellent. The provisions obtained last fall as an advance on treaty money are lasting very well, and represents a very definite benefit to the people. The trip was made with little expense. I went with the H.B.C. man and his dog team. He was making a trading trip and I ran with the train. We made about sixty miles in a long day on the homeward trip and I arrived in good condition. I expect to make yet another trip later on. The trip was accomplished between Sundays and no services were cancelled here.

We have still a number of people on the Reserve, these who could not leave for various good reasons and our school attendance will average about 17. We have very little sickness and four new babies born, all doing well.

A rather remarkable condition has become apparent in making up statistics for Mission information. We have approx. 180 people on the Band. Of these 90 are children from infancy to the age of 14. The great majority of these latter are between the ages of infancy to 10 or 11 years. This is going to present a considerable school problem in the near future. I have the assurance of Mr. Graham that he has sanctioned a new school in the present years estimates. This does not mean of course, that the school will be built this year. In view of the figures given above it would appear expedient that sufficient school accommodation should be provided in a new building. I think this matter should be taken up with the Department.

There is the difficulty of the band obtaining a winter living, however. To do this it is necessary for the families to spend some months in the bush, or at the fishing stations in the summer. This procedure has been the definite instructions of the Department this winter, and would seem to be very necessary, but it seriously interferes with the education of the children. If compulsory school attendance is enforced, the families cannot go to the bush or the fishing stations and we should have a return to the destitution experienced last winter.

The only solution I can see to the difficulty is compulsory boarding school attendance for all children with the mental and physical qualifications. This is an
extreme step, but the benefits would be very apparent, both to
the children, and the parents, which latter would then be free
to follow their natural pursuits. If the matter were mooted now
it would cause considerable opposition, but I am sure the idea
would grow, and, if the Government were eventually induced to
consider it, especially as it would be a means to the economic
betterment of all these bush Reserves and therefore an easing
of Governmental financial support, much of our Indian problem
might thus be solved. I realise the expense of enlarging the
schools etc., but this would be less than the financial
liability which the bush Indians are bound to become in the
not distant future. To follow this up, with the children in
the boarding schools and fitted for responsible life, the
outside settlement arrangement as suggested by Mr. Beaton, could
then be made effective.

Admitting the measure is extreme, some extreme
measure will have to be resorted to.

Since the New Year I have added four adult and
three juvenile Catholics to the Church roll. I do not think I
told you the R.C.'s had purchased a small building on the
Reserve, evidently with the intention of starting a school.
As there are now only six Catholic adults and one infant in
the Band it is altogether unlikely that anything will come
of this movement. It is quite possible that the whole
Reserve will be United Church before the end of the year.

I have thought that it would be an excellent
thing to have printed (preferably in English and Cree) a
family Church Membership roll in the form suitable for
framing, with space for the names of all the family, so
that each family could identify themselves by the possession
of one of these on the wall of their house. The psychological
effect would be excellent. Would it be possible to obtain
these?

I have been able to send in a small donation
to the M & M fund so that our annual report will not show
blank. I expect however, a larger donation from the Band in
the Spring. It is gratifying to know that the Chief has
himself suggested this donation spontaneously, which is as it
should be. I am more and more appreciating the attitude of
the Chief. We are on the most friendly and co-operative terms,
and he invariably refers to me as his "dear brother".

My returns show a membership increase of 75
as compared to 57 last year.

There is one matter which has been bothering
me and which I would like your advise on. Some of my
correspondence, mostly on Church matters, is addressed to
me as "Rev." I had occasion to take the matter of wolf
depredation and prospective bounty with the Government and
I was referred to recently on the radio as "Rev". I have
corrected this matter in some cases, but it is manifestly
inexpedient to do so always. I never sign myself by this
title and I feel that I am sailing under false colours.
Do you think that I should correct this error in all cases?

Our family are all well and happy and we trust
that you and Mrs Barner are also. We had a very pleasant
Christmas and Christmas tree. I took Santa Claus to the
children at Thunder Lake.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Barner,

Further to my letter to you of January 29th. In my report of the number of children tributary to Poplar River School it would be read that there are 90 children from the age of infancy to years in the Poplar River Band. This is rather misleading as 19 of this number are non-treaty children, but these will be dependant on the Poplar River School when they are of school age. We have two attending the school now.

I have compiled a list of the children and their ages to give you some definite information. In this letter I will not take into account the non-treaty children, although these should not be neglected, as in no case are the parents able to send the children out for an education.

Among the treaty children you will note that the ages are evenly divided, 34 out of the total of 67 being at present of school age. It is apparent, however, that the birth rate is increasing, also, that the infant mortality has decreased considerably during the last few years. This decrease will assuredly be maintained, as better methods have been introduced in infant care. The eight children under one year are in perfect condition.

If I might digress to comment on the prospects of these infants, I may say that their chances of life, while greatly increased by better care, are still woefully handicapped by living in draughty, ill-ventilated dwellings and by, in almost every case, contamination from T.B. infects in the same dwelling.

Our present seating accommodation in the school is 24, including some old desks. This takes care of our present roll, the average for this quarter being about 17.

I must confess I am all at sea in regard to the education problem. If our people are to follow their natural pursuits, which they must do to make a living, then a winter school is all that can be maintained, attended by about one half of the children of school age, the other half being at the trapping grounds with their parents. The children attending school in the winter are drawn from families who are in receipt of support from the Government, by reason of widowhood or disability, or who are too indolent to exert themselves to make a living. As the school children are provided with good meals at the school, the situation would appear to handicap those who are industrious enough to leave the reserve to make a living.

The summer problem is more difficult still. If the summer migration was to a location where definitely established and permanent work was provided,
the school could follow the children, but the work is distributed between Black River, George's Island and Poplar Point. It is true that most of the people were at Black River last year, but this year there is a prospect of the sturgeon fishing being opened, which will distribute the people more widely.

Had I been successful, while yet the fishing administration remained with the Federal Government, in obtaining a segregation of territory in the mouth of the Poplar River for pickerel fishing exclusively for the Band, they might have been held together, and school facilities arranged, but, the pickerel fishing being closed, and the administration now being with the Province, this arrangement is very remote, although it would still be feasible and without detriment to other organised fishing, could the Province be induced to make this concession.

I realise that the problem pertaining to Poplar River, is accentuated on all the other reserves, especially those inland, and, this being so, I can see no other way in bringing education to the Indian children, education which is imperative in the process of emancipation, other than the establishment of collective educational institutions. The time is not opportune for anything definite to be done, but it is not too early for the idea to be sold to the Government.

Under the existing circumstances it is evident that on the Poplar River Reserve, 50% of the children will receive less than half the benefits of a day school education and 50% will receive no education whatever, and this compares favourably with other Reserves.

It might be asked why so few children of this Band are attending boarding school. This desirability has been stressed, but the consent of the parents must be obtained, and there seems to be a decided antipathy towards the boarding schools, principally due to the fact that mortality has been very high among those who have been sent to the Boarding School from this Reserve. This fact, of course, may be purely coincidental.

I do not think we should fight shy of the compulsion in this proposed school attendance. After all, the white race are under compulsion to educate their children and also to provide a living for themselves.

We have had a very mild winter, with no destitution. The prospects for the Spring catch are excellent. The winter catch has been good, but the very low fur prices have tended to make what might have been a prosperous season into an indifferent one.

With Kindest regards from Mrs Caldwell and myself,

Yours very sincerely,

As previously reported the Poplar River School building is in very poor condition. The building is a frame structure on a log foundation, apparently poorly constructed in the first place. The log foundation has rotted, and the floor is sunk and the walls bulged in places. The lumber has shrunk to such an extent as to be no longer weather proof. The building is difficult to heat during the winter, and impossible to keep warm during severe or windy weather.

During the past winter the attendance has been small as many of the Reserve families were away at their trapping grounds all winter. The fur catch was poor, especially in the Spring, and the people have expressed their intention of staying on the Reserve, or at least leaving their families on the Reserve, next winter. This will mean a much increased attendance at the school next winter, and it is very important that a new building should be erected. Owing to the condition of the foundation and the condition of the walls, it does not appear that any repairs could be undertaken on the present building with any profit.

According to present statistics there will be Thirty children of school age belonging to the Band resident on the Reserve at the beginning of the next school year.

Dear Sirs,

I wish to acknowledge Department letter 125-14-1 dated July 21st, which deals with the school attendance at the Poplar River Indian Day School.

I have discussed the situation with Mr. McPherson, the Indian Agent, and we are of the opinion that the school should be open on this reserve during the months of August, September, October, November, December, January, February, March and April. This will allow school to close at the end of April for break-up and the rat season, after which the Indians generally go to Big Black River for summer fishing which takes place in June and July.

I am quite aware that the Indians of this reserve must be out on the trap lines during the winter months if they are to make a living and in view of this fact no doubt the attendance will not be good. On the other hand, the summer school is out of the question in view of the fact that the Indians are employed at fishing at Big Black River. I would therefore recommend that we carry on for another year as suggested above.

Dear Sirs:

Re - Poplar River Indian Day School

With further reference to your letter of January 2nd and to Dr. Cochrane's conversation with you, there are one or two facts which we believe should be in the possession of your Department before final decision is made.

It would appear from correspondence we have received that Mr. Taylor was in touch with Mr. McPherson some time in the summer concerning the possibility of his opening the school on August 1st instead of September last - which was the old arrangement, - so that he could get in the required number of months, and yet get a month off, either in November or December, so that he might be with his wife in Winnipeg at the time of the expected arrival of their first child. Certainly, Mr. McPherson wrote to Mr. Taylor on August 9th a letter, copy of which I enclose. From this you will note that Mr. McPherson says that he had written to the Department about the possibility of Mr. Taylor's opening the school on August 1st.

When we received a letter from you, advising us that the Poplar River Indian Day School would be in operation for only nine months, we wrote at once to Dr. Cormie, asking him to communicate this decision to Mr. Taylor. On October 7th, Mr. Taylor wrote to Dr. Cormie and in this letter he says that the same week a boat had docked at Poplar River, bringing him a letter from Mr. McPherson, which conveyed the same decision. Mr. Taylor was rather taken aback, as he had hoped that, by teaching in August, he would have November or December off. In his letter to Dr. Cormie, he says:

"I came back here in good faith that Mr. McPherson would get the necessary permission for me to have November or December off if I taught in August. He advised me to take such a course and in letters I received as late as September last, he advised me as to procedure to follow before leaving the reserve. This led me to believe that permission would be granted as a matter of form and the letter I received from Mr. McPherson, with no reference to my request (made early in July) ignores it but implies refusal by placing the month of my regular holidays that I had taught in the newly arranged teaching year."
When Mr. Taylor says that Mr. McPherson ignores the request, but implies refusal by placing the month of his regular holidays that he had taught in the newly arranged teaching year, he is, of course, giving his own interpretation of what Mr. McPherson may or may not have had in mind.

In view of this, I think that some of the statements contained in Mr. McPherson's letter should receive, at least, some further consideration. In the first paragraph, Mr. McPherson says that Mr. Taylor left his school on the 25th October "without permission from Inspector Hamilton or this office." It is no doubt true that he was not aware that Mr. Taylor had left until the 7th December, but he certainly knew that he intended to leave.

As to whether Mr. Taylor left his school, without permission, in the latter part of June, - my impression is that there was no school going on during that month, and that was precisely the reason why your Department felt that school should only be carried on for nine months. There is nothing in our correspondence which leads us to the belief that Dr. Cormie had given any permission to Mr. Taylor to leave - certainly it is not in any correspondence which we have from Dr. Cormie. I believe it is correct to say that Mr. Taylor came down at the beginning of freeze-up under the impression that Mr. McPherson knew about it and that he had written to the Department.

In the second place, it should be noted that this year the weather was so mild that there was no plane service for a considerable length of time between the first frost and the date when it was possible to operate the planes on the ice. This will account for the fact that Mr. Taylor was so long away.

I hope that you will give the matter further consideration and that, in any event, you will look into the reason why Mr. McPherson wrote to Mr. Taylor on August 9th and said, "I have written the Department but as yet have had no reply," and now no mention is made of Mr. McPherson's communication with the Department.

Yours sincerely,

GD.MLT

Dear Sirs:

I have your letter of January 23rd, enclosing copy of letter which you have received from Mr. McPherson. With regard to the fourth paragraph of your letter, I quite definitely agree that the teacher should have approval in writing before absenting himself from school during the school term.

I have read Mr. McPherson's letter. It may be that there was a misunderstanding, but if I were a teacher and got a letter, dated August 9th, from an inspector to whom I had written, and in that letter the following paragraph occurred -

"With reference to you opening your school on August 1st, I have written the Department but as yet have had no reply. I wish to point out to you that if you get permission to have December off, you must issue the December rations before you leave."

I should certainly take it for granted that the two sentences in the paragraph had reference one to the other - that is, "written to the Department" and "permission to have December off" - and I most certainly do not agree with the Agent's explanation that the sentence had nothing to do with Mr. Taylor's leave of absence. Mr. Taylor wrote in July to Mr. McPherson. At that time he had no notice from the Department that the school year was to be changed. Neither had Mr. McPherson. The reason that Mr. Taylor requested Mr. McPherson to write you, asking for permission to open the school on August 1st was precisely in order that he might have either November or December off, so that he might be with his wife in Winnipeg. When Mr. McPherson says that it was in connection with the proposed change in the school term of the Poplar River school and had nothing to do with leave of absence, perhaps he would explain why he wrote to Mr. Taylor on August 9th about this matter, when it was only on September 11th that he notified him that the school term had been changed.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 24th instant, relating to the operation of the Poplar River Indian Day School.

I do not know that any useful purpose can be served in continuing the correspondence between your office and this Department in respect to Mr. Taylor's action in leaving the school without first having secured permission. Your letter, however, would indicate that a misunderstanding exists, either in your mind or mine, in respect to the whole matter. I have made a careful perusal of the letters here on file, relating to the period during which the school should be operated. There are letters here from the Indian agent, Mr. McPherson, and from Inspector Hamilton, in respect to the matter. Both the Inspector and Mr. McPherson were anxious to find ways and means of conducting the school in such a way that the school would not be open when the Indians were away, in May and June, for rat trapping and fishing. There is nothing on file that I have been able to discover that even suggests that the teaching period was changed to permit Mr. Taylor to visit Winnipeg in either November or December. I must state, however, that the paragraph quoted by you and taken from Mr. McPherson's letter of August 9 may have leant itself to a misinterpretation.

One point I want to emphasize in writing this letter is that the abandonment of his school by an Indian day school teacher, without having first secured permission from the Indian agent or the Department, is a very serious matter and looked upon as such by the officials. When a teacher abandons his school without notice, the Treasury Officials continue to pay his salary and his salary cheques are sent out monthly. When it is discovered later that he has not been engaged in his regular teaching duties, it is almost impossible in some cases to secure a refund of the salary paid. This fact in itself leads to endless correspondence and negotiations between this Branch and the Treasury officials and between the Treasury officials and the Department of the Auditor General. In fact, it would be wholly impossible to administer 234 schools, employing 389 teachers, if the practice of abandoning their schools became general on the part of teachers. The other point I want to emphasize is that it is not our intention that

Mr. R.A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare and Training, Ottawa.

I received your letter of December 8th file number 125-14-1 regarding Mr. Shanks distributing rations on the reserve. I wish to advise you that when I took over this agency all rations on the reserves were handled by the Missionaries. Some years ago I requested the Department to allow me to have the Hudson Bay handle our rations at Poplar River and Little Grand Rapids as I was not satisfied with the way the Missionaries were handling them. Also at Berens River I had the R.C.M.P. take over the rations. As there are no Hudson Bay stores at any of the other reserves the Missionaries have always handled them and I find that they have done a very satisfactory job and no complaints from the Missionaries and very few from the Indians.

The Missionaries have always been instructed that no-one gets rations that is able to work and I feel satisfied that this has been carried out. This summer Mr. Talbot, District Manager for the Hudson Bay Company informed me that they were closing their store at Poplar River and that I would have to make other arrangements for the rations. There is no-one more fit to handle the rations at Poplar River other than Mr. Shanks and at the time the Hudson Bay closed I wrote Mr. Shanks requesting him to take the rations over. He wrote me and said he would be only too pleased to do so. I had the Manager of the Hudson Bay, who has been handling the rations for some years, give Mr. Shanks a list of those who receive rations and Mr. Shanks has been using this list as far as I know.
I interviewed Mr. Shanks in Selkirk before he left for Poplar River and gave him all the instructions I could for the length of time the boat was at dock at Selkirk. When he arrived at Poplar River, he wrote me requesting more information which I immediately wrote him and gave him all the information he requested.

I wrote and told him that he would receive $3.00 per month for 9 months for the janitors work at the school and $50. a year for dispensing drugs.

If Mr. Shanks is not willing to handle the rations as other Missionaries are doing, I wish you would please advise what steps I should take.

E. McPherson,

Dear Sir,

It is apparent from your letter of the 23rd ultimo that you were not fully informed regarding the situation at Poplar River about which I wrote.

If Mr. McPherson wrote on Oct. 15, 1942 that I had deferred opening school until August the 16th without cause he did not state the case as it actually was. I had requested that major repairs be made to the school building and Mr. McPherson led me to believe that they were being forwarded. If you wish to have his letter I will forward it. Would it seem reasonable to you to open school then immediately close it to have the repair work done, it did not seem so to me. Please bear in mind that at Poplar River I had no way of contacting the Agent, to get instructions. I expected the repair material to arrive daily and so did not open school. It is apparent to me that Mr. McPherson wrote the letter dated Oct. 15, 1941 which you mention out of personal animosity as he had clearly placed himself in the wrong by promising material which had never been purchased. It was he not I who held up the opening of school, I was at Poplar River ready to commence on August 1.

You state that I had no authority from your branch to keep school open after April 30, 1942, may I point out that on the other hand I had no authority from the branch to open on August 1 either, as the Branch seems to infer. The only communication I received from the Branch was a circular giving October 1 as the opening date. I only supposed that school should be opened on Aug.1 because that was the date I had opened in 1940, however even that year Mr. McPherson twice changed the date.

From the above it will be apparent to you, I am sure, that I attempted to discharge my duty fully as teacher at Poplar River even to making up
days which were lost through no fault of mine. After serving the Branch in three different schools and attempting carry on my work as teacher to the best of my ability it seems strange to treated thus by a department of the government.

It is interesting that Mr. McPherson should write as he did on Oct. 15, 1941 as the same year the Indian school at Berens River was closed while the teacher went in to Winnipeg without permission. Mr. McPherson told the teacher to make up the days lost if possible, if not, not to worry. This teacher lost no salary and did not make up the days.

I am sure that when you have given the above facts your consideration you will agree that I am justly entitled to the two weeks salary I am asking for.

Yours truly,

H. Meadows
Ottawa,

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 7th instant, in which you enclosed the June quarter return of the Poplar River Day School, I beg to say that the salary of this teacher is paid to the Treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society, Toronto.

It is noted from the return that the school was only open for ten days during the quarter and it has been decided that the Department can only allow payment for one month. A cheque for the amount due, viz., $85.00 is being forwarded to the Treasurer of the Missionary Society, who will pay Mr. Lee.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.
Ottawa, June 11th, 1926.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the June quarter return of the Poplar River Indian Day School. The return shows that the school was only open from April 1st to April 16th, about which time the Indians left the reserve and the school was consequently closed. It has been decided to allow only one month's salary and a cheque for $85.00 is being forwarded to your Treasurer.

The Indian Agent at Selkirk in forwarding the return states that Mr. Lee has left Poplar River and is at present undecided where he will be located.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. C.E. Manning,
General Secretary Home Missions,
Wesley Buildings,
299 Queen St., W.,
Toronto, Ont.
Ottawa, June 9th, 1926.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that the Church authorities have nominated Mrs. Glam M. Caldwell, wife of the missionary who has recently been appointed to Poplar River, to take charge as teacher of the Indian Day School at that point. Mrs. Caldwell has a Second Class Certificate for Saskatchewan and Manitoba, and has had eight years' experience. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $95 per teaching month. We understand that she and her husband will proceed to Poplar River in July, next.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. O. Latulippe, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

We are in receipt of yours of December 20th, re the September quarterly Report.

In this regard may I advise you that Mrs Caldwell found it necessary to go to Winnipeg at the beginning of September and was operated on at the Victoria Hospital for appendicitis and other abdominal troubles, on the 8th of that month. We arrived home at Poplar River on October 1st, and opened school on Oct., 3rd. The journey was undertaken on the advice of Mr. Barnet, whom we met at Selkirk when on our return journey to Poplar River at the beginning of August. Mr. Stevenson, the Indian Agent, was also advised of the delay in opening the school.

The first opportunity we had of sending mail from here was about the middle of December, therefore we delayed sending the blank return for the September Quarter until the December Return was completed. Both these returns are now going forward.

Realising that a medical certificate will be required to validate the closing of the school, we are, this mail, requesting Dr. Leggett of Winnipeg, the operating surgeon, to forward such a certificate to you at Brandon. We trust that this will be found satisfactory.

We have had an average attendance of 14.55 during the last quarter, out of a total number of 20 children on the Reserve of School age. We had, however, an outbreak of chicken-pox, and thought it advisable to close the school from October 10th to October 21st inclusive. The number of cases was confined to seven.

Mrs Caldwell and myself wish to thank you for your kind wishes for the New Year and also to wish you the greetings of the season.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Re Poplar River Indian Day School.

I duly received the communication of your Mr. Russell T. Ferrier under date of July 21st - File No. 125-14-13 - in reference to the salary of the teacher of the Poplar River Indian Day School. I am now able to give you the explanation for the school's being kept open only four days during the June quarter. Our Superintendent of Indian Missions, Rev. Arthur Barnet, in a letter from Lake Winnipeg, dated August 12th, states:

"The Poplar River Reserve is very much broken by waterways. In the spring and fall these are quite impassable. About 1924 a boy was drowned while crossing broken ice on his way to school. Since then the people will not run any risks, so that every June quarter report is small. Mrs. Caldwell says that she makes notes of these things on the reports. The reason the attendance was smaller than usual this year is because the breakup was earlier. Mr. Caldwell thinks that by building two foot bridges the school days might be increased. He is taking up this matter with the Agent at Treaty this week. In May the people leave for the fishing grounds and take their families with them."

I understand that when a condition such as is above described has existed in other seasons, the Department has been good enough to forward to this office the cheque for that particular quarter, although the school may not have earned the full amount. I trust that the Department will see its way to forward the cheque for the June quarter. The amount, as already reported to the Department, has been paid the teacher for that quarter.

Yours faithfully,

JNS.MLT

Dear Sir:

RE POPLAR RIVER RESERVE

Your favor of the 10th instant, #125-14-5, addressed to Rev. R. B. Cochrane, D.D. is to hand regarding the payment of $95 which the Department intends shall cover the salary of the teacher at the Poplar River Indian Day School for one month instead of for the full quarter.

In reply would say that I would ask the Department to kindly consider the economic conditions which prevail at that Reserve. The Indians are forced to move to Black River at the beginning of the fishing season. Black River is twenty miles by water from Poplar River, and as is generally known, the Indians take their families along with them so that the constituency for the school is beyond reach. If the Department would provide suitable accommodation at Black River, Mrs. Caldwell, the teacher, has intimated that she would be very glad to continue the school at that point.

Owing to the situation thus created, the Indian Agent paid Treaty at Black River this summer instead of at Poplar River.

I would also draw the attention of the Department to the fact that Mr. Caldwell has been throughout the entire year caring for the needy and destitute on the Reserve without any remuneration from the Government, and as the Indian Agent visits Poplar River only once a year, Mr. Caldwell has the full responsibility of their oversight.

In view of the facts above stated, I feel that the Department should carry the expense of the school at Poplar River for the entire school year, and I shall be glad to receive a cheque for the balance of the teacher's salary for the quarter ended June 30th, 1931.

Yours very sincerely,

Ottawa, July 5th, 1932.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the June quarter return of the Poplar River Indian Day School and it is noted that the school was only open for eleven days during the quarter. You will, no doubt, remember that there was some correspondence in connection with this school last year.

Careful consideration has been given to the June quarter return and it has been decided that, this year, the Department can only allow two months' salary. A cheque for this amount, viz., $190., less 10%, is being issued and sent to your Treasurer.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. Kenneth J. Beaton, B.A.,

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

July 18th,
1932.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

Your letter of July 15th, informing us that the Department can allow the teacher at the Poplar River Indian Day School only two months' salary for the June quarter, is to hand.

I suppose when everything is taken into consideration that this is probably a fair division of the responsibility for Mr. Caldwell's salary between the Department and the Church. It is, of course, through no fault of the teacher that he cannot carry on until the end of June, as they do in most of the other schools. Last year I remember discussing this matter with him when we were at the Norway House Conference. It was his suggestion that Mr. Indian Agent MacPherson should pay Treaty at Black River, where the Indians go for the fishing, in place of at Poplar River, and while he spends the time there with his people, there is no building which could be used as a school-room. Besides, I am sure we all recognize that once the children have been scattered and their attention diverted, as would undoubtedly happen in the moving of the Band from Poplar River to Black River for the fishing season, the attempt to get them back into school would be almost certain to fail.

The Department have been very considerate in regard to the grants made for the Poplar River School and we are willing to accept the decision contained in your letter of July 5th as final for the current year.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

Ottawa, August 5th, 1933.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the June quarter return of the Poplar River Indian Day School. It is noted that the school was only open for twelve (12) days during the quarter. This was due to the same reasons as previous years and, in this connection, I might refer you to official letter of July 5th, 1932, and your reply of July 18th, 1932.

The teacher, Mrs. C. M. Caldwell, is, I understand, the wife of the missionary and resides at Poplar River. Last year, the Department allowed two months' salary for the June quarter. The Department feels that we should not allow more than this amount this year.

Have you any information regarding the time these Indians return to reside on the reserve? It is possible that, in the case of this school, it would be preferable to have it open from, say, July 1st or August 1st until April 30th of the succeeding year. I would appreciate an expression of your views regarding this suggestion as it is necessary to have some definite understanding in connection with this school due to the fact that our payments are very carefully scrutinized at the present time by the Auditor General and it would be difficult for us to explain why two months' salary is allowed when the school is only open for such a short period during the June quarter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Toronto,
Aug. 18,
1933.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: Poplar River Indian Bay School
(File No. 125-14-8)

The situation at Poplar River has not changed since our correspondence of July 1932.

The Indians go off fishing before the end of May, sometimes early in April, and the holding of school is impossible. So far as I know they do not return until the whitefish season is over, usually the end of August or early in September. It is satisfactory to us to accept two months' salary for the June quarter.

I am not sure that the Department of Indian Education is the one that should carry all the burden for caring for this band of Indians, but certainly the Indian Department is under a tremendous debt to the missionary and his wife at that point. I just discovered incidentally, for instance, that Mr. Hamilton, the Inspector, has never been at Poplar River. As a matter of fact the Indian Agent has not been there for at least three years unless the acting man went in this year. They pay Treaty now out on the lake where the Indians congregate for the early fishing. There is no doctor nearer than Selkirk and the missionaries are responsible for a great deal of medical work. In addition to that they have given constructive leadership in the matter of rebuilding the homes of the Indians which were destroyed by the disastrous fire of three years ago, along the line of co-operative buying and reduction of individual debts, and in the development of agricultural plots, particularly potatoes. My personal opinion is that the Board of Home Missions of the United Church and the Department of Indian Affairs have few servants more efficient and more worthy of support than Mr. and Mrs. Caldwell.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

FORM 14
Ottawa, June 20, 1935.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the authorities of the United Church of Canada, under whose auspices the Indian Day School on the Poplar River Reserve is being conducted, have nominated the services of Mrs. Davis M. Baird, B.A., as teacher, to succeed Mrs. A. E. Caldwell. The Department is advised that Mr. and Mrs. Caldwell are being transferred to become principal and matron, respectively, at the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, B.C.

Mrs. Baird is a graduate of the University of New Brunswick, has had two years' teaching experience and holds a first class permanent certificate. Her husband, Rev. E. M. Baird, B.A., B.D., will be the missionary on the reserve. The Department is approving the appointment of Mrs. Baird as from September third, next, the date the school re-opens after the summer holidays. The salary allowed will be at the rate of $96 per teaching month.

I have to request that you will give Mrs. Baird every possible assistance in the work at this school.

Yours obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Andrew Irwin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.

Sir,

I have the honor to forward requisition for school material and furniture from Mr. J. A. Distrow, Teacher, Poplar River School.

In this connection I beg to state that the children are attending more regularly now, consequently the 6 forms and 2 tables supplied are insufficient to seat them.

The flexible black board supplied the school is now useless, as the chalk will not adhere to it. The same complaint is made from other teachers who have been furnished with black boards of the same material, a wooden one is asked for.

As soon as the ice breaks up in the spring the Indians move down to the mouth of the river for the purpose of fishing, when it is impossible for the pupils to attend, as it is too far away and dangerous for them to travel to the school, inclement and obstructions in the way by land. There is therefore generally a very small attendance during

E. McCall, Esq.,
Inspector of Ind. Affairs,
Winnipeg, Man.
during the spring, summer, and fall, so that a tent large enough to accommodate the pupils would be useful and convenient during that time. But as the school was moved to the same grounds every spring and remained there until late in the fall, I believe that a simple frame house constructed out of single matched siding for walls, shingled roof, and a matched floor, would be the best and cheapest at least. For if the material was furnished the Indians could put it together themselves without cost to the Department.

It would last longer than canvas and protect the children better during bad weather. The school material, furniture, and livestock would be safer than in a tent. Therefore should the Department see fit to supply the material for a building such as above described, I add below the quantity of lumber required:

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter alluding to the purchase of 10 sacks of flour from Mr. Hyre, for the Indians of the Poplar River Band, and in reply to your enquiry to inform you that I had no direct authority to make the purchase.

I arrived at Poplar River Reserve on the evening of the 13th of April of last year, and found the Indians of that Band in very destitute circumstances, very few fish had been taken for a week or two previously, and game was very scarce. Outside of these two sources these Indians had nothing within reach to gain an existence from, and at the time of my visit I do not believe they were getting one meal per day. Traders Hyre and Campbell held a few sacks of flour on the Reserve for trading purposes, and they demanded 10 fox skins per sack for it, and which in my opinion was equivalent to $7.50 per sack, with chances of realizing $10.00 for the skins. There were 14 poorly clad children at the School, and I was sure that some had come without a morsel of breakfast, and poor chances for either dinner or supper. I took possession of five sacks of Mr. Hyre's flour, and handed it over to Mr. Dargue to issue to the children who attended the School, at the rate of 10 oz. per pupil for a full day's attendance, and I authorized Mr. Dargue to get five more sacks in the event of the Indians not getting any fish. I may say that there were no biscuits on hand to issue, neither had there been for weeks before; in fact the teacher had not made up the School returns for two or three Quarters previously, owing to his inability to get forms from the Agent.

The attendance at the School increased to about 42, and the small issue of flour was the attraction. I think that Mr. Hyre placed a small valuation on the flour, when he could, without question, have made at least 50 per cent more out of it.

Yours obediently,

Sgd. J.A. Markle,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

The inclosed Voucher is for painting and other work done on the Poplar River Day School:

First the item of five dollars for nails

Authority had been given to expend one hundred dollars to complete the building and lumber was sent out from Selkirk but the nails were forgotten and then it was too late in the season to write about it so the teacher Mr Blackford who was asked to superintend the work secured the nails himself and had the work done.

Second the item of forty five cents for lock

This lock was for the old School House which is used for storing biscuits and supplies for the destitute and it was a necessity.

Third the item Two Dollars and Fifty Cents

This was for bringing the lumber 1000 ft. from Poplar Point where it was left by the steam boat to the Reserve a distance of ten miles.

Fourth—the item of 25.00 for painting

This is included in the vote of fifty dollars for painting the building; but I have reduced it to fifteen dollars because I consider the charge unreasonable in view of the fact that the teacher closed the school while he was doing the painting.

With these explanations I trust the Voucher may go through.
I have the honor to be

Ottawa, March 6, 1912.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Semmens reports that the Poplar River Day School building is very cold and that a new stove is needed.

When you visit Winnipeg in the spring you will be good enough to purchase a suitable stove for the use of this school and arrange to have it sent to its destination. You will be good enough to consult with Mr. R. H. Simson, Winnipeg, who will inform you as to where this purchase should be made.

The Department would like to know what you consider should be done to make this building more comfortable, as some action will have to be taken during the coming summer.

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, June 14th, 1921.

Sir,

The teacher of the Poplar River Indian Day School, in his annual report for the last fiscal year, states that the foundation, which is of wood, has quite rotted away.

I will be pleased if you will, upon the occasion of your next visit to this Reserve, make an inspection of the building, and furnish a report as to its present condition and what is required in the way of repairs to the foundation and approximately the cost of having the work done.

During the summer of 1920, material was supplied to the amount of $255.00 for repairs to the building, and I may say that it was considered at that time that the quantity of material supplied would have completed all repairs to the building.

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, July 5th, 1921.

Sir,

The June Quarterly Return of the Poplar River Indian Day School has been received.

The teacher, Mr. Hope, requests that a new stove be supplied. He states that a stove the size of the one at present in the school be obtained. If the present one is unfit for use, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a new stove. Before making the purchase, you should obtain competitive prices and make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. You may also purchase any stove pipe necessary.

You will be good enough to give this matter your early attention in order that the new stove can be forwarded during the present summer and set up ready for use when the cold weather commences.

You should furnish properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the stove, stove pipe and any freight charges. You should also attach a memorandum giving the names of the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted by them.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

The repairs of this school which were authorized last year have not yet been completed. The work is being done by the teacher Mr. W.J. Hope after school hours and during holidays. When completed I will report to the Department.

Dear Mr. Latulippe,

Enclosed please find school and medical returns for quarter just closed. It was hard to find anyone capable of fixing the school seats so I did it myself and it took a long time and I used a lot of carriage bolts, screws etc. I had a man help me clean the pipes and paid him seventy-five cents and wrote supplied a length of new pipe so I think the enclosed account very fair. It will need a complete outfit of new stove pipes next year and I shall make out a requisition next spring in plenty of time to have them come in with the treaty supplies. Every child has had measles but it is practically done with now. Conditions of everything on the reserve quite satisfactory.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a requisition from Mrs. A. E. Caldwell, teacher of the Poplar River Indian Day School, for classroom supplies and for various articles of clothing for the pupils of the school.

With reference to the Day school, I sent forward the return for the quarter ending 31st December, 1926. This shows favorably as to attendance, the food assistance in 1 meal to the children and the 2 biscuits to the children have placed for the children their means of sustenance and adds to their better health conditions. Mr. Caldwell asks for the following supplies for the pupils of the Day School. The greater attendance makes it necessary to furnish some more biscuits:

- 8 boxes of Biscuits are needed for the pupils for the daily meal to each pupil in attendance daily, the following will be required:
  - 300 lbs White beans,
  - 100 " Rice,
  - 100 " Sugar, granulated
  - 20 " Cocos,
  - 6 doz. Mild, Borden's (or 2 cases)

The attendance has increased, in fact the attendance has about trebled, being for quarter ending 31 Dec, 1925, 4.5 and for the quarter ending 31 Dec 1926, 13. These conditions will in my opinion explain why Mr. Caldwell the teacher finds it wise to provide these extras. Finding the improved conditions I feel that this sufficient warrant for me to recommend the purchase and help to hold up the advantages gained.

All of which is submitted and recommended.

Mr. Caldwell leaves on Friday the 28th, and he would like to hear before he leaves. Please wire me.

Your obedient servant,

J. R. Bunn,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Stevenson:

I am enclosing you herewith requisitions for the yearly school supply. In the matter of the desks which are requisitioned for you ask for the makers name of the desks on hand. There does not appear to be any name on them. They are a mixed variety. The number of desks ordered will not accommodate the whole school, as there are 28 children on the roll this quarter, and five more of school age who have been at the trapping grounds this quarter and whose names do not appear on the roll, but I will be able to utilise some of the old desks by making one out of two, if the desks on order are supplied.

The closets for the school are a very necessary requirement, as the only accommodation which the children have at present is the surrounding bush. This may have been considered sufficient when the attendance was limited to about six daily, as it was some two years ago, but the growing attendance demands better conditions. I have figured a closet which would be satisfactory but if the Department wishes another style built, a plan of this could be sent to me. It appears to me necessary, however, to have separate closets for the girls and boys.

You will notice that I have asked for an increase in the school rations. I have found it necessary to purchase recently another 100 lbs of beans from the H.B.Co here to complete the term. I have done this at my own expense and trust that the Department will see the advantage of supplying the required amount this year.

Re the additional dishes required. While we have 15 on hand, the daily attendance often exceeds this number.

Yours very truly

(signed) A.E. Caldwell.

Report re Patrol from Bernes River to Poplar River Indian Reserve and return.

While at Poplar River reserve, I visited the school-house and found a very good attendance; there has been an average of 20 pupils attending this last quarter, the school-house here requires a considerable lot of repairing. It should be lined with wall-board on the interior, and new floor and brick chimney, with paint both for interior and exterior. The school is very cold this winter for the children.

H. A. Stewart.
Ottawa, January 10, 1931.

Sir:

The Department has received from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police a report regarding a patrol made to the Poplar River Indian Reserve. A visit was made to the school, and a good attendance was found. It is stated that the school building requires considerable repairs, and that it should be lined with wallboard on the interior, a new floor and brick chimney installed and both the interior and exterior of the building painted.

I have to request that on the occasion of your next visit to Poplar River you will make an examination of the school building, and inform the Department of the repairs required to place this building in good condition. An itemized statement should be given as to the work required and the approximate cost of same, also how you would recommend that the work be carried out. When we have this information, consideration will be given to authorizing having the repairs required carried out next summer.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt of Indian Education,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your annual report form, just received owing to the condition of the ice. It is unlikely that you will receive this form completed until sometime in June, when it will be sent from the nearest point of call for the boats.

May I suggest that the form for this point be sent somewhat earlier, say in February, so that we may be able to get it mailed to you on the last ice mail?

May I request you also to give your attention to the remarks re the condition of the school building? I am aware that the Department is unlikely to wish to undertake any expense during the present time of depression, but it is absolutely necessary that something be done to provide a more comfortable building for the children. The foundation has rotted, and the ship-lap boards with which the building is lined, have dried to such an extent as to be no longer weather-proof. The walls also are bulging owing to the lack of foundation support.

As the register during the past five years will show, the attendance has been steadily increasing, and it is our wish to have this increase maintained. More desk accommodation is needed, but this should be taken up only after something is decided about the building.

May I suggest that the labour of a new school building would be of great benefit to the whole reserve this summer or fall, as the labour conditions at the fishing stations are not good, and it would be greatly more desirable to spend money in this way rather than to supply rations to the band.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I have to refer you to official letter of January 10th, last, regarding the repairs required to the school building at the Poplar River Indian Day School. A report has been received from the teacher regarding the condition of this building. He states that the foundation is rotting and that the shiplap boards with which the building is lined have dried to such an extent as to be no longer weatherproof.

We will have no funds this year to provide for the erection of a new building, and, as it will be necessary to carry out the minor repairs required to make the building as comfortable as possible for the next school year, I have to request that you will furnish a report regarding the repairs which you would recommend be carried out, stating the approximate cost of any material and labour required. Only the work absolutely necessary should be considered. Your report should be forwarded as soon as possible, in order that any work authorized can be carried out before the cold weather sets in next fall.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

A New School at Poplar River.

Repeated representations have been made to us by our missionary at Poplar River that a new school building is urgently needed. I understand that the present building is in such a bad state of repair that he has been advised by the Agent or his deputy to give up trying to conduct classes in the building during the winter, if the weather becomes particularly inclement.

Judging from our experience in rebuilding at Poplar River after the fire of two years ago, we have in Mr. Caldwell a very fine building supervisor. I understand, also, that Mr. Indian Agent McPherson and Commissioner Graham are recommending that a grant be placed in the estimates for next year for this purpose. I feel sure that Mr. Caldwell can erect the building at a minimum of expense, and that it would be the part of wisdom, if the money can be obtained at all, to let him proceed with the work. Certainly, from our standpoint, no group of Indians on Lake Winnipeg have made the progress in the last three years that those at Poplar River have made under Mr. Caldwell's guidance and leadership.

Your attention to this matter will be very greatly appreciated.

Yours very sincerely,

Sir:

Requisition of July 15th, for supplies for the Poplar River Indian Day School, has only reached the Department today. It is noted that the last steamer leaves Selkirk on the 12th instant. The Department is of the opinion that arrangements should be made to have these requisitions forwarded much earlier in the year, in order that due consideration can be given to what articles can be allowed.

- 3 cases Condensed Milk
- 150 " Rice,
- 24 bars Soap,
- 40 " Cocoa,
- 1 Scrubbing Brush,
- 10 " Salt,
- 1 Axe Handle,
- 2 Brooms,
- 6 Panes of Glass,
- 1 lb. of Putty.

Water pails, kettles, basins, an axe and a number of the other articles requested on the requisition this year were supplied last year. The Department sees no reason why it is necessary to again secure them, if reasonable care was taken of the supplies previously allowed.

As pointed out in the first part of this letter, it is impossible to have the school supplies shipped in time to catch the boat on Monday, next. Please let me know how these supplies can reach the school. Your reply will be awaited before an order is placed.

Your obedient servant,

Selkirk, September 11th, 1932

Sir:

In reply to your letter #125-14-5 of the 9th instant, referring to the requisition for mid-day meal supplies for the Poplar River Indian Day School, I beg to inform you that the date of the sailing of the last Steamer, leaving Selkirk for Black River, has been changed from September 12th to September 21st.

The supplies, authorized have been purchased, and will be forwarded direct on that date.

If the Department will forward the school supplies at once, they may arrive in time to catch that boat. If not, they can be forwarded to Berens River and from there by mail carrier to Poplar River before navigation closes.

The delay in forwarding this requisition was owing to the mail service from Poplar River, being only once a month. It was forwarded from this Office, to Ottawa the day it was received.

Selkirk, Man., September 20, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer to your letter of July 21st, File 115-14-5, relative to paint and repairs for the Poplar River Indian Day School. I am very sorry that I have been unable to make a report on this sooner as I wrote Mr. Meadows on receipt of your letter but have just received a reply owing to the poor mail service to this point.

In our letter to Mr. Meadows we requested that he supply us with a list of materials required to repair the school and asked him to advise if he would rather have paint supplied or repairs made, as we could not supply both. He informed me that it would be impossible for him to give an estimate of the repairs required as he is not a builder. I also informed him that the Department would not allow anything for the labour of putting the paint on. He stated in his letter that if nothing was allowed for putting on the paint, there was little use in supplying it.

I consider that Meadows can get along for another year without paint or repairs to his school and I would recommend that this matter be left over for the time being.

Very truly yours,

E. Moppherson,

Poplar River Indian Reserve School - #1950

There is need for a new school and teacher's residence at Poplar River Indian Reserve. Our present facilities do not include a teacher's residence, the United Church manse being used as teacherage. The school was improved to some extent last summer having been insulated with saw-dust from our saw mill on the Reserve, and other minor repairs effected.

During our recent discussion in Winnipeg it was agreed our present inadequate facilities could not be replaced prior to 1950 but might then be erected. Assuming this having some validity may I make the following suggestions.

We have a sawmill and planer on the Reserve. If supplied a bill of materials required for standard one room school and teacherage we could supply locally a large percentage of building requirements to mutual advantage of local Indians and at great saving to Department. Of course, windows, doors, flooring, and some finishing materials would have to be shipped in. I would ascertain what we could advantageously supply after obtaining bill of materials. If this is acceptable our logging operation this winter would be accordingly increased for sawmill cut during summer 1949, then dry piled for use in spring and summer of 1950, if school were then to be built.

The foregoing plan would, perhaps, entail joint consideration by Education and Welfare Branches. The Branch is well aware of Poplar River as the problem band of this Agency. It seems feasible, if any plan put into effect were to be mutually advantageous, it should receive consideration. I submit the foregoing proposal merits consideration.

It would be beneficial to me to know probable reaction before the end of January in as much as our winter logging operation at this reserve will be affected accordingly.

B. E. Olson,
Supt. Clandeboye Agency.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that at my visit to the Pas Mountain in January last the Red Earth Band requested that now they may be supplied with a School Teacher.

In this connection I would respectfully remark that I consider these Indians should be encouraged in their desires after progress in civilization. For some time I have observed a decided and growing desire on their part in this direction, and trust therefore that so long as the rising generation of these heathen Indians may receive the benefits of education.

I beg further respectfully to inquire, in the event of the Department granting the request of these Indians, what steps are to be taken in the erection of a school house, and if the same shall be established at the Indian Village. It is a suitable locality, as you yourself are personally aware, though it is not on the Reserve, but is asked for by the Band in exchange for their River portion. It should also be noted that the School Houses hitherto built in this agency are very unsatisfactory buildings.

circumstances as myself might not be employed on the Indian Reserves.

In reference to letter 128/8/1 of the 16th inst. advising me that Mr. J.C. Ash will continue as teacher of the Red Earth Day School until June 30th next.

I beg to state that I visited the Red Earth Indian Day School on Sept. 20th. The teacher had left the reserve to visit The Pas, and would not be back to teach school until about the 27th. During the month of September the school had been open nine days to the time of my visit. The teacher had remarked in the register for the first week of September that there were no children present on the reserve and the school was not opened during that time, but upon inquiring I was informed by the Indians that Mr. Ash was not on the reserve himself during the first few days of the month, but there were fifteen children waiting there to attend school. I saw Mr. Ash on the morning of the 20th when he was on his way to The Pas, and he told me there were no school children on the reserve so he was going to Town. I saw some school children on my arrival, and the Indians informed me that there were fifteen children ready to go to school that day.

I do not know just what to recommend in this case, as the teacher seemingly takes more interest in his own affairs than he does in those of the Department, but I think it would be well to ask His Lordship, the Bishop of Saskatchewan, to endeavor to have us supplied with another teacher by January 1st.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Work of School.

The tone and spirit of the school are good.

The following lessons were observed: Grade II, language. The assignment was definite and purposeful. Grade V, Maths. Lessons of good type. Assignment very definite. In all mathematics classes the work was well organized, the work definite and dealt with everyday problems. Reviews were taken in many subjects and were based on old examinations.

Citizenship tests given were good. Snaptests show that in Grade I some pupils are weak in reading and comprehension. Grade II on the whole show satisfactory progress. The middle grades show satisfactory progress while the senior grades have made fair progress. In mathematics progress of the middle grades is satisfactory.

Note that Health Education is stressed. I feel that proper and desirable habits are becoming fixed and that the attitude of the pupils is
many cases are improved.

Unfortunately some of these people have been carried on paylists at the same time we were paying them on voucher and this has led to further complications.

The situation is not particularly due to anyone's neglect or fault, but I think it requires direction from you as to how these people should be paid. My recommendation is that all dispensers and issuers of rations should be paid on voucher and under no circumstances should appear on paylists. The first thing to do as I see it is to make a clear distinction between dispensers of drugs and issuers of rations. I will undertake to be responsible for the appointment and payment of the former, the latter it seems to me, are administrative employees.

The Representative of the Treasury complains justly of this state of affairs.

R. L. Stone, M.D.

FORM 14
Ottawa, January 13, 1927.

Right Rev. Sir:

I beg to draw Your Lordship's attention to official letter of the 11th ultimo, relative to the resignation of Mr. J. G. Ash, teacher of the Red Earth Indian Day School, and requesting that you nominate the services of a teacher having the necessary qualifications to succeed him.

In order that this school will not remain closed, and the children be deprived of school facilities, the Department is, on the recommendation of Mr. Agent Waddy, appointing Mr. Isaiah Badger as teacher until such time as the services of a qualified teacher can be nominated by Your Lordship. We will allow Mr. Badger salary at the rate of $60 per teaching month during the period he is engaged.

I would request that Your Lordship make an early nomination of a teacher having the necessary qualifications to carry on the work at this school, and that you will forward for the approval of the Department full particulars as to the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated by you.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

I beg to inform you that the Church of England authorities have nominated the services of Mr. J. T. Blewett for the position as teacher of the Red Earth Indian Day School. Mr. Blewett has 2nd Class Academic standing and 3rd Class Professional Normal for the Province of Saskatchewan. The Department is approving of his appointment with salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month. We understand that Mr. Blewett has proceeded to Red Earth and that he is in all probability at work there at the present time. I have to request that you will give him any assistance you can in his work at this school.

I beg to refer you to your letter of the 4th ultimo and the Department's reply thereto of the 15th of the same month, relative to the temporary appointment of Mr. Isaiah Badger to carry on the work at this school until a teacher was appointed. Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

The building in which the day school at Red Earth is being conducted by Mr. Kennedy is said to be in very bad condition and it would require an expenditure of about $200.00 to repair it. Before authorizing this expenditure Ven. Archdeacon MacKay was asked whether, in view of the early completion of the new boarding school at The Pas, this day school would be required. A reply has been received from him in which he states that he is inclined to the opinion that even if a few of the children are sent from Red Earth to The Pas school there would still be enough remaining to make it desirable to continue the day school at Red Earth.

I find on looking up the census return that there are 26 children of school age on the reserve. Twenty-one of these were enrolled in the school during the September quarter and the average attendance was only 8.6 for that quarter and for the past year 10. If all the
the children of school age were enrolled at this school there should be an average attendance sufficient to justify its continuance, even if a few of the pupils were recruited for The Pas Boarding School.

Mr. Inspector Jackson, who recommended that an increase be given to the teacher, stated in his letter to the Department that he considers Mr. Kennedy one of the best of the old teachers that are employed. The increase was granted and he is now in receipt of a salary of $400.00 per annum.

Would it not be well to have the building repaired, as recommended by Mr. Agent Taylor? If this is done the Agent should be instructed to see that the attendance is regular.

Sir,

I have the honor to enclose the report from the teacher at Red Earth Reserve day school for the September quarter.

I visited this school on the 2nd inst., and found 14 boys and 7 girls present. I examined the children and found they have made progress in their studies. The pupils in the higher grades could do practically any sum or question in the text books but got flustered when set questions relating to sale of bale offur containing pelts of different values. I instructed the teacher to get busy on questions of this sort which will crop up during the after years of his pupils.

The pupils at this place pick up the work very quickly after starting school, but it is hard to advance them past the second standard on account of absences from school.

The school building was very clean, but requires 2 panes of glass 14 X 28, I would be obliged for authority to purchase same at cost of about $2.00.

The storehouse at this point flooded through the roof leaking, and spoiled a lot of biscuit. A new roof will cost $50.00 and should be built in spring of 1923. This hardly comes under the educational department, but as it is mixed up under school supplies and destitute supplies perhaps you can get a grant of that amount next spring, at which time I will take the matter up again.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that Isaiah Badger, the school teacher of Red Earth day school, has asked me if I will apply to the Department for assistance to the amount of $200.00 to help him put up a house, as his old shack at Red Earth is in bad shape. This man offers to pay back $25.00 per quarter if the money is advanced to him. The money to be taken out of his school salary.

This teacher is a treaty Indian, of the Red Earth band, and if he loses his position at any time there would be no way in which we could collect the money from him. However, he is teaching the school in a very satisfactory manner, and I do not anticipate any trouble with him. I beg to recommend that the Department allow him up to the sum of $150.00 of material and freight charges, if there are any funds on hand for this purpose.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

Luncheons had been provided at noon by one of the Indian women cooking the food as the teacher is a bachelor and could not attend to it. The food had been used up too fast and was about gone. The teacher stated that the system was not satisfactory and that he would like to see it done away with as when the grub was brought to the school to be eaten it messed up the desks and he had trouble in keeping the place sanitary. I talked the matter over with the Indians and they said it would be well to quit it for this year. Under the circumstances I told the teacher to store away our dishes and equipment, and gave the rest of small food supply to the woman who had cooked all winter.

I have authority to put logs under the walls of the school. On sizing up the place it would appear as if this would only be a temporary arrangement and a waste of money as the building will have to be replaced in another year or so in any event, these old log places are unsatisfactory. The Indians have not got any equipment for raising the place to put in a foundation.

DAY SCHOOLS:

The party then went on to Red Earth, after the completion of the payments, the teacher of the day school Mr. J.G. Blewett, he assembled his pupils, fifteen in all, he put them through a course of exercises such he would work out in a regular school day, classes are elementary, but they seem to know what had been taught to them in a fairly clear manner, and they all sang well, hymns, the national anthem and O Canada were very well rendered. The school building is log walls which require some badly required repairs, the floors should also be levelled, the sills, so far as I could judge, are rotted and should be renewed, a new stove would add to the comfort, door and windows seem to be alright; if made a little more weather tight it would be more comfortable, the furniture seems to be adequate; desks, table for teacher and chairs are all in fair shape. The teacher is dispenser and looks after destitute supplies, he is an unmarried man, he is in his probation period, his objective being to take holy orders. The school teacher at Shoal Lake is also a dispenser.

J. R. Bunn,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, October 22, 1928.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Bunn, in a report on his visit to the Red Earth Indian Day School during treaty payments, states as follows:

"The school building has log walls which badly require repairs. The floors should also be levelled. The sills, so far as I could judge, are rotted and should be renewed. A new stove would add to the comfort. Door and windows seem to be alright. If made a little more weather tight it would be more comfortable."

If it is not too late in the season, you may arrange to have any needed repairs made to the building in order to make it as comfortable as possible during the coming winter. You should, as far as possible, arrange to carry out the suggestions of the Inspector regarding the doors and windows in order to make them weather tight. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to make the best arrangements, before the extreme cold weather sets in, in having the repairs absolutely required carried out. You may also purchase a new stove of a type that would be satisfactory.

Please keep all expenses as low as possible, and forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The matter of supplying a new stove should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
