September 14th 1929.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that last summer Chief Isaiah Badger constructed a fence around the residence of the school teacher at the Red Earth Reserve, using material that the Department had supplied last year I understand. He also repaired the school fence.

He then asked this office to take up with the Department the matter of payment for his labor and on investigation it appears that he put in sixty fence posts, stretched the wire etc., and put up a gate. He also put the school fence in order which was a small matter. The teacher thinks that $15.00 would be ample for his work, but Mr. Waddy tells me that if the man gets $10.00 he will be well paid, as under ordinary circumstances the job should have been done in a day or day and a half by Badger and his helper.

I would be obliged if the Department will advise me if a voucher for this work may be submitted for payment and for what amount.

WINNIPEG, MAN. July 9th, 1935.

RED EARTH INDIAN DAY SCHOOL,
THE PAS AGENCY

Sir:-

An inspection of this school was made on Wednesday, June 6th, 1935. Mr. B. T. Plunkett is in charge here, but I believe he is being transferred. He has done splendid work and I regret the Church has seen fit to recommend the change.

There are 26 pupils enrolled and the grades are as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 14     |
| II    | 3      |
| III   | 4      |
| IV    | 3      |
| V     | 2      |

These pupils have greatly improved since my last inspection. They are more alert and speak much better English. The exercise books were neat and the handwriting good.

The children are well mannered and splendid discipline is maintained. All the pupils were well dressed and clean in appearance.

This is a log school, but it is in fair repair.

The teacher's residence should be placed on a foundation. The floor has given way along one side, allowing mice and other pests admission to any part of the house. The building is of frame construction and well worthy of the necessary repairs. It will be practically

Dear Sir,

Re Red Earth School building, Saskatchewan.

Mr. Indian Agent Lovell, Mr. Lowe the Teacher and Chief Badger have consulted together about this matter, and have asked me to write to you about it.

I think the Bishop of Saskatchewan wrote about it some time ago.

During the last few years the number of this band of Indians has increased, and the number of children attending school has increased considerably.

There are now 28 children attending school, and the size of the building is 23 by 17 feet. There is no porch, and quite insufficient seating accommodation. I visited the School on Oct. 8th, and there were 27 children in attendance that day. Some of the small children were sitting three in a desk, and an arrangement of boxes had to be used for some of the children to write on.

Under the circumstances I thought the children were making very good progress, but the crowded conditions make it impossible for the pupils to do the best possible work.

It is an old log building, cold in winter, and should be replaced by a new building.

We found it necessary to build a new Church there two years ago; and the School needs replacing just as much as the Church did. Again the site of the building is unsuitable and dangerous for small children, as a few feet from the School fence is a sheer drop into the Carrot River. During recent years the flood waters in the Spring have overflowed from the lake into a natural cut-out a few yards from the school, and have eaten away the bank of the river, forming the abrupt drop of which I speak.

There is a very suitable site South-West of the present school, on the other side of the Teacherage, and I would suggest to you
Ottawa, November 6, 1936.

Venerable Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, regarding the condition of the present school building on the Red Earth Indian Reserve and requesting that provision be made to erect a new building, on a new site, southwest of the present school, with accommodation for at least thirty children.

In reply I have to say there were so many demands for new day school buildings and for repairs and alterations, that it was not possible, when preparing the Estimates for the coming fiscal year, to include an item providing the funds required for the erection of a new building at Red Earth. However, the need at this point will be kept in mind.

The Department will give favourable consideration, next spring, to providing some new desks and carrying out any minor repairs necessary to make the building more comfortable, until it is found possible to provide funds to erect a new building.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6246, file 539-5, part 2)
Dear Sir,

We have, as you know, put down in the 1940 estimates for a new School for Red Earth Reserve. The old School is in very bad shape and it is also much too small for the number of pupils it has to accommodate. The Ven. W.E. J. Paul has been pressing for a new school for this point for a number of years.

If we are going to build this school during the coming summer, it will be necessary to get the logs out and on the site during the winter. It would be practically impossible to do this during the summer, as there are no roads and much of the land around Red Earth is swamp. I would therefore like your authority to engage the Indians to cut logs and haul them to the site. I estimated this would cost $110.00.

It would be far better too if the material could be purchased and hauled in during the winter. Summer freighting is extremely difficult. The material should be purchased at Carrot River, Sask. It is out of the question to purchase the material here as it would mean shipping it by rail 500 miles to Carrot River and then it would have to be trucked in to Red Earth.

As far as I know there are no firms on the preferred list at Carrot River. There are two firms dealing in lumber and building supplies there. Lang Bros, Carrot River and the Beaver Lumber Co., Carrot River, Sask. I would like this material to be purchased so that it could be delivered by March 15th at the latest. After that date the roads are liable to be bad.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6246, file 539-5, part 2)
Ottawa,
January 24, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 17th instant regarding your request for a new school on the Red Earth Reserve.

Very careful consideration was given to your request for a school on this Reserve but due to the fact that definite instructions were received to curtail expenditure to the greatest possible extent it was not possible to include an item for this school in our appropriation for the year 1940-41. Under these circumstances it will not be possible to proceed with the erection of a new school at this point during the summer of 1940.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
